eng: we mean fundamental change in the structure, systems, institutions and patterns of ownership, management and control of the economy in favour of all south africans, especially the poor, the majority of whom are african and female, as defined by the governing party, which makes policy for the democratic government.
sot: re bolela phetoho ya bohlokwa sebopehong, tsamaisong, ditheong le mokgweng wa boithuelo, bookamedi le taolo ya moruo molemong wa maaforika borwa ohle, haholoholo ba kojwana di mahetleng, bao boholo ba bona e leng maaforika ebile e le ba batshehadi, jwalokaha ho hlalositswe ke mokga o busang, o etsang maano a mmuso wa demokrasi.

eng: twenty-two years into our freedom and democracy, the majority of black people are still economically disempowered.
sot: dilemong tse 22 tsa tokoloho ya rona le demokrasi, boholo ba batho ba batsho bo ntse bo sa matlafatswa moruong.

eng: they are dissatisfied with the economic gains from liberation.
sot: ha ba a kgotsofala ke tse fumanwang moruong ho tloha tokolohong.

eng: the gap between the annual average household incomes of african-headed households and their white counterparts remains shockingly huge.
sot: sekgeo dipakeng tsa meputso e tlase ya malapeng e kenang ka selemo malapeng a maaforika le a ba basweu ka ho le leng se dutse se le seholo ka ho nyarosang.

eng: white households earn at least five times more than black households, according to statistics sa.
sot: malapa a ba basweu a fumana kahodimo ho malapa a ba batsho ka makgetlo a mahlano bonnyane, ho ya ka dipalopalo tsa aforika borwa (stats sa).

eng: the situation with regards to the ownership of the economy also mirrors that of household incomes.
sot: maemo mabapi le boithuelo ba moruo a boela a bontsha ao a ditjhelete tse kenang malapeng.

eng: only 10% of the top 100 companies on the johannesburg stock exchange are owned by black south africans, directly achieved principally, through the black empowerment codes, according to the national empowerment fund.
sot: ke 10% feela eo e leng ya maaforika borwa a matsho dikhamphaneng tse lekgolo tse kahodimodimo phapanyetsanong ya ditjhelete le diabo ya johannesburg (jse), e ileng ya atleha, ka mananeo a matlafatso ya ba batsho, ho ya ka letlole la naha la matlafatso.

eng: the pace of transformation in the workplace, the implementation of affirmative action policies as required by the employment equity act, 1998 (act 55 of 1998) also remains very slow.
sot: sekgahla sa phetoho mesebetsing, ho kenngwa tshebetsong ha maano a tekanyo ya menyetla jwalokaha ho hlokeha ho molao wa tekanyo mesebetsing, 1998 (molao wa 55 wa 1998) le sona se sisitheha haholo.

eng: in terms of the 2015/16 information submitted to the employment equity commission, the representation of whites at top management level amounted to 72% while african representation was at 10%.
sot: ho ya ka lesedi la 2015/16 le kentsweng khomisheneng ya tekanyo mesebetsing, boemedi ba basweu ditulong tse hodimo tsa bookamedi bo ne bo fihla ho 72% ha boemedi ba maaforika bo ne bo le ho 10%.

eng: the representation of coloureds stood at 4.5% and indians at 8.7%.
sot: boemedi ba batho ba mmala bo ne bo eme ho 4.5% mme ba maindia ho 8.7%.

eng: the report further provides that white south africans, in particular males, are afforded higher levels of recruitment, promotion and training opportunities as compared to the designated groups.
sot: tlaleho e boela e tswelapele ka hore maaforika borwa a masweu, haholoholo banna, a fuwa menyetla ya boemo bo hodimo ya kgiro, ho nyollwa mesebetsing esita le thupello papisong le dihlopha tse qollotsweng.

eng: at the level of gender at senior management level, males remain dominant at 67.6% and females at 32.4%.
sot: boemong ba bong ditulong tsa bookamedi bo boholo, ba batona ke bona ba bangata ka 67.6% athe ba batshehadi ba ho 32.4%.

eng: the skewed nature of ownership and leadership patterns needs to be corrected.
sot: sebopeho se matswedintsweke sa mekgwa ya boithuelo le boetapele se hloka ho otlollwa.

eng: there can be no sustainability in any economy if the majority is excluded in this manner.
sot: ha ho ka ke ha ba teng botsitso moruong ofe kapa ofe haeba bongata bo kotetswe ka mokgwa ona.

eng: in my discussions with the business community, they accepted these transformation imperatives.
sot: dipuisanong tsa ka le ba kgwebo, ba dumellane le diphetoho tsena tsa bohlokwa.

eng: today we are starting a new chapter of radical socio-economic transformation.
sot: kajeno re phetla leqephe le letjha la phetoho e matla ya moruo wa setjhaba.

eng: we are saying that we should move beyond words, to practical programmes.
sot: re re re tlameha hore re se ke ra bua feela ka molomo, empa re qale ho kenya mananeo tshebetsong.

eng: the state will play a role in the economy to drive that transformation.
sot: mmuso o tla ba le seabo moruong e le ho akofisa phetoho eo.

eng: in this regard, government will utilise to the maximum, the strategic levers that are available to the state.
sot: ntlheng ena, mmuso o tla sebedisa ka botlalo, disebedisuwa tsa mawa tse teng mmusong.

eng: this includes legislation, regulations, licensing, budget and procurement as well as broad-based black economic empowerment charters to influence the behaviour of the private sector and drive transformation.
sot: sena se akga ketso ya melao, melawana, ho ntshuwa ha dilaesense, bajete le phumantsho esita le ditokomane tsa matlafatso ya motheo o batsi ya ba batsho moruong ho susumetsa boitshwaro ba lekala la poraefete le ho ntshetsapele diphetoho.

eng: the state spends r500 billion a year buying goods and services.
sot: mmuso o sebedisa r500 bilione ka selemo ho reka thepa le ditshebeletso.

eng: added to this is the r900 billion infrastructure budget.
sot: hodimo ha yona ke bajete ya r900 bilione ya meralo ya motheo.

eng: those budgets must be used to achieve economic transformation.
sot: dibajete tseo di tlameha ho sebedisetswa ho fihlella diphetoho tsa moruo.

eng: as a start, the new regulations making it compulsory for big contractors to subcontract 30% of business to black-owned enterprises have been finalised and were gazetted on 20 january.
sot: e le ho qala, melawana e metjha e etsang hore e be tlameho hore dikonteraka tse kgolo di theolele 30% ya mesebetsi ya tsona dikgwebong tseo e leng tsa batho ba batsho, e se e phethetswe mme e phatlaladitswe ka la 20 pherekgong.

eng: through such regulations and programmes, government will be able to use the state buying power to empower small enterprises, rural and township enterprises, designated groups and to promote local industrial development.
sot: ka melawana e jwalo le mananeo, mmuso o tla kgona ho sebedisa matla a ho reka a naha ho matlafatsa dikgwebo tse nyane, dikgwebo tsa mahaeng le tsa makeisheneng, dihlopha tse qollotsweng esita le ho phahamisa ntshetsopele ya diindasteri tsa lapeng.

eng: two key challenges we face are the high levels of concentration in the economy and the collusion and cartels, which squeeze out small players and hamper the entry of young entrepreneurs and black industrialists.
sot: diphephetso tse pedi tse ka sehloohong tseo re tobaneng le tsona ke tshubuhlellano e kgolo moruong esita le mmomori wa dikhamphane wa ho etsa selekane sa ditheko le boqitolo ba ho nyolla ditheko, e leng tsona tse qhelelang bahwebi ba fokolang thoko ebile di sithabetsa ho kena ha batjha ba bahwebi le boradiindasteri ba batsho.

eng: the competition authorities have done excellent work to uncover the cartels and punish them for breaking the law.
sot: makgotla a ditlhodisano a entse mosebetsi o kgabane wa ho nyebokolla maqitolo esita le ho a fumantsha kotlo ka ho tlola molao.

eng: last year i signed into law, a provision to criminalise the cartels and collusion and it came into effect on 1 may.
sot: ngwahola ke tekenetse hore e be molao, karolo ya ho etsa hore e be tlolo ya molao boqitolo le mmomori mme e qadile ho sebetsa ka la 1 motsheanong.

eng: it carries jail sentences of up to 10 years.
sot: e fupere kahlolo e fihlellang dilemong tse 10 tjhankaneng.

eng: we are now stepping up our actions to deal with the other challenge, namely economic concentration, where a small grouping controls most of a market.
sot: jwale re mothating wa ho tiisa meqheleba dikgatong tsa rona tsa ho sebetsana le phephetso e nngwe, e leng tshubuhlellano moruong, moo sehlopha se senyane se laolang boholo ba mebaraka.

eng: during this year, the department of economic development will bring legislation to cabinet that will seek to amend the competition act, 1998 (act 89 of 1998).
sot: monongwaha, lefapha la ntshetsopele ya moruo le tla fa kabinete molao o entsweng o tla be o habile ho hlomathisa molao wa ditlhodisano, 1998 (molao wa 89 wa 1998).

eng: it will, among others, address the need to have a more inclusive economy and to de-concentrate the high levels of ownership and control we see in many sectors.
sot: ho tse ding, o tla rarolla tlhokeho ya ho kenyelletswa ho tomanyana moruong esita le ho notla sekgahla se hodimo sa boithuelo le taolo seo re se bonang makaleng a mangata.

eng: we will then table the legislation for consideration by parliament.
sot: jwale re tla tekela palamente molao oo o entsweng hore e o lekole.

eng: in this way, we seek to open up the economy to new players, give black south africans opportunities in the economy and indeed help to make the economy more dynamic, competitive and inclusive.
sot: ka mokgwa ona, re habile ho bula moruo ho ba nang le thahasello, re fe maaforika borwa a matsho menyetla moruong re be re etse moruo hore o be mahlahahlaha, o qothisane lehlokwa o be o kenyeletsa bohle.

eng: this is our vision of radical economic transformation.
sot: ena ke tjhebelopele ya rona ya phetoho e matla ya moruo.

eng: compatriots,government is actively involved in the property sector, having provided more than four million houses since 1994. this sector in our country is valued at approximately r7 trillion, with the subsidised sector being valued at r1.5 trillion.
sot: baheso,mmuso o itahletse ka setotswana lekaleng la matlo, mme o se o fane ka matlo a fetang dimilione tse nne haesale ho tloha ka 1994. boleng ba lekala lena naheng ya rona bo ho r7 terilione, ha ba lekala le tlatseletswang ka ditjhelete bo le ho r1.5 terilione.

eng: however, less than 5% of the sector is owned or managed by black people and africans in particular.
sot: leha ho le jwalo, beng ba karolo e katlase ho 5% ya lekala lena kapa bolaodi ke batho ba batsho mme ke maaforika haholoholo.

eng: a draft property practitioners bill will be published by the department of human settlements for public comment with the purpose of establishing a more inclusive, representative sector, towards radical economic transformation.
sot: bili ya nakwana ya barekisi ba matlo le meaho e tla phatlalatswa ke lefapha la bodulo ba batho bakeng sa ditshwaelo tsa setjhaba ka sepheo sa ho thea lekala le kenyeletsang bohle, le nang le boemedi ha tomanyana, ho habilwe phetohong e matla ya moruo.

eng: among key priorities this year, government will also address the increasing delays and backlogs in registration and issuing of title deeds to beneficiaries of housing projects funded by the capital subsidy.
sot: ho tse ding tsa dintho tse ka sehloohong monongwaha, mmuso o tla boela o rarolla taba ya ditieho le ditshallomorao tse eketsehang ngodisong le ho ntshuweng ha mangolo a ho ba monga thepa ka botlalo ho bafola molemo ba diprojeke tsa matlo a lefelletsweng ka tjhelete ya tlatseletso.

eng: compatriots,we reiterate that radical economic transformation should mean moving beyond share ownership schemes only.
sot: baheso,re thasisetsa hape hore phetoho e matla moruong e tshwanela ho bolela hore ho hahamallwa ka nqane ho dikema tsa boithuelo ba diabo feela.

eng: we would like to see black people involved directly in business, owning factories.
sot: re lakatsa ho bona batho ba batsho ba itahletse ka setotswana ka kotloloho dikgwebong, e le beng ba difeme.

eng: the development of the black industrialists programme is thus critical.
sot: kahoo, ntshetsopele ya lenaneo la boradiindasteri ba batsho le bohlokwa.

eng: the programme has from inception supported more than 22 entrepreneurs.
sot: haesale la na la thewa, lenaneo lena le tsheheditse bahwebi ba kahodimo ho 22. mmuso o na le menyetla e meng diprojekeng tsa tlhokomelo ya matlo ya lefapha la mesebetsi ya setjhaba.

eng: government has further opportunities in the property maintenance projects of the department of public works.
sot: lefapha le tla tsetela r100 milione monongwaha mananeong a bohlokwa a ditjhelete tsa ho qala kgwebo le tlhokomelo ya thepa, ho ntlafatsa dibaka tsa boemakepe.

eng: the department will invest approximately r100 million this year on critical capital and maintenance programmes to modernise harbours.
sot: ba tla boela ba tswelapele ho bokella tjhelete e kenang ka ho hirisa dibaka tsa boemakepe boo e leng ba mmuso le meaho e ka lebopong la lewatle, e tla thusa di-smme tseo e leng tsa batho ba batsho.

eng: they will also continue generating revenue from letting state-owned harbours and coastline properties, which will benefit black-owned smmes.
sot: mmuso o tla boela o tswelapele ho sututsa maano a habileng ho batsisa seabo sa batho ba batsho le di-smme, ho akga le tseo e leng tsa basadi le batjha, lekaleng la lesedi le theknoloji ya dikgokahanyo.

eng: we assure the youth that the lowering of the cost of data is uppermost in our policies and plans.
sot: re tiisetsa batjha hore ho theolwa ha ditjeo tsa data ke ntho ya bohlokwa maanong le mererong ya rona.

eng: compatriots,mining has always been the backbone of our economy and an important foreign exchange earner.
sot: baheso,haesale merafo e ntse e le tshiya ya moruo wa rona ebile e le baamohedi ba bohlokwa ba diphapanyetsano tsa bolata.

eng: we welcome the recovery in commodity prices, which has resulted in an upswing in mining output.
sot: re amohela tsosoloso dithekong tsa dihlahiswa, e bakileng hore dintho di ye tsullung tlhahisong ya merafo.

eng: this augurs well for the industry.
sot: sena se thophothela hamonate diindastering.

eng: the mining charter is currently being reviewed.
sot: tokomane ya merafo e ntse e shejwabotjha hajwale.

eng: the charter seeks to recognise the internationally accepted right of the state to exercise sovereignty over all the mineral and petroleum resources within the republic.
sot: tokomane e habile ho ananela tokelo e amohelehileng matjhabeng ya mmuso ya ho nka taolo ya mehlodi yohle ya dirafshwa le peteroliamo kahare ho rephaboliki.

eng: it is also aimed at helping the country to de-racialise the ownership of the mining industry.
sot: e boetse e reretswe ho thusa naha ho fedisa semorabe boithuelong ba indasteri ya merafo.

eng: this will help to ensure the sustainability of this industry.
sot: sena se tla thusa ho netefatsa boteng ba botsitso indastering ena.

eng: we trust that discussions between government and business on the charter will yield results so that the process can be finalised.
sot: re tshepa hore dipuisano tse dipakeng tsa mmuso le kgwebo ka tokomane ena di tla bea ditholwana ho etsetsa hore mosebetsi o phethelwe.

eng: we will continue to pursue direct state involvement in mining.
sot: re tla tswelapele ho sututsa taba ya ho kenakena ha mmuso ka kotloloho ho tsa merafo.

eng: the mining company of south africa bill will be presented to cabinet and parliament during the year.
sot: bili ya dikhamphane tsa merafo tsa aforika borwa e tla tekelwa kabinete le palamente ha selemo se ntse se rwalellana.

eng: the minerals and petroleum resources development amendment bill was sent back to parliament so that issues relating to the public consultation process undertaken by provincial legislatures can be addressed.
sot: bili ya sehlomathiso ya ntshetsopele ya mehlodi ya dirafshwa le peteroliamo e ile ya busetswa palamenteng ho etsetsa hore dintho tse amanang le mosebetsi wa ho buisana le setjhaba tse entsweng ke makgotla a ketsamelao a diprofense di rarollwe.

eng: we trust that it shall be processed and returned for finalisation without much delay so that the concerns relating to uncertainty raised by business can be resolved.
sot: re a tshepa hore e tla sebetswa e be e kgutliswe hore e ilo phethelwa ntle le tiehiso e kgolo, ho etsetsa hore dingongoreho tse amanang le qeaqeo tse hlahisitsweng ke ba kgwebo di rarollwe.

eng: government continues to work with other stakeholders to combat illegal mining to save lives and to prevent the trafficking of precious metals and diamonds.
sot: mmuso o tswelapele ho sebetsa le ba bang ba amehang ho lwantsha merafo e seng molaong, ho pholosa maphelo le ho thibela ho kgukguniswa ha mahakwe a bohlokwa le ditaemane.

eng: we also continue to place great emphasis on the health and safety of mineworkers, which is so crucial to the sustainability of the mining sector.
sot: re boetse re tswelapele ho tsepamisa maikutlo ho bophelo bo botle le polokeho ya basebetsi ba merafong, e leng ntho ya bohlokwa ka hofetisisa boitjarong ba nako e telele lekaleng la merafo.

eng: working with the mining companies we can ensure that lives are protected at all times.
sot: ha re sebetsa mmoho le dikhamphane tsa merafo re ka netefatsa hore maphelo a sireletswa ka dinako tsohle.

eng: the tragic accident that occurred at lily mine in mpumalanga earlier in 2016 is the first of its kind that we have experienced since the dawn of democracy.
sot: koduwa e etsahetseng morafong wa lily mpumalanga pejana ka 2016, ke ya pele ya mofuta wa yona eo re e boneng haesale ho ne ho fihle demokrasi.

eng: the families are going through immense pain and frustration.
sot: malapa a mahlonokong a maholo mme a thefulehile.

eng: compatriots,it will be difficult if not impossible, to achieve true reconciliation until the land question is resolved.
sot: baheso,ho tla ba boima haeba ho sa tlo kgoneha ho hang, ho fihlella poelano ya nnete ho fihlela taba ya mobu e rarollwa.

eng: only eight million hectares of arable land have been transferred to black people, which is only 9.8% of the 82 million hectares of arable land in south africa.
sot: ke dihekthare tse dimilione tse robedi feela tsa mobu o ka lengwang o fetiseditsweng bathong ba batsho, e leng 9.8% feela ya dihekthare tse 82 milione tsa mobu o ka lengwang aforika borwa.

eng: there has also been a 19% decline in households involved in agriculture from 2.9 million in 2011 to 2.3 million households in 2016. we had stated our intention of using the expropriation act, 1975 (act 63 of 1975) to pursue land reform and land redistribution, in line with the constitution.
sot: ho boetse ho bile le phokotseho ya 19% malapeng a neng a lema ho tloha ho 2.9 milione ka 2011 ho ya ho 2.3 milione ka 2016. re ile ra hlakisa maikemisetso a rona a ho sebedisa molao wa kamoho ya mobu, 1975 (molao wa 63 wa 1975) ho sututsa tlhabollo ya mobu le kabobotjha ya mobu, ho ya ka molaotheo.

eng: i have now decided to refer the bill back to parliament for reconsideration on the basis that it might not pass constitutional master.
sot: jwale ke qetile ka ho busetsa bili ena palamenteng hore e ilo lekolwa botjha ka lebaka la hore e ka nna ya se ke ya atleha bookameding ba molaotheo.

eng: we trust that parliament will be able to move with speed in meeting the requirements so that the law can be finalised to effect transformation.
sot: re a tshepa hore palamente e tla kgona ho akofa ho kgahlanyetsaneng le ditlhoko tsena, ho etsetsa hore molao o phethelwe mme ho kenngwe diphetoho.

eng: the reopening of land claims is also still on hold because the restitution of land rights amendment act, 2014 (act 15 of 2014) was declared invalid by the constitutional court.
sot: pulobotjha ya ditseko tsa mobu e sa ntse e emisitswe hobane molao wa sehlomathiso wa ditlhapiso tsa ditokelo tsa mobu, 2014 (molao wa 15 wa 2014) o ile wa tsebiswa o se molaong ke lekgotla la molaotheo.

eng: the constitutional court found that the public consultation process facilitated by the ncop and some provincial legislatures, did not meet the standard set in the constitution.
sot: lekgotla la molaotheo le fumane hore mosebetsi wa ho buisana le setjhaba o hlophisitsweng ke ncop le makgotla a ketsamelao a diprofense tse ding, ha o a ka wa fihlella maemo a beilweng ke molaotheo.

eng: going forward, government will continue to implement other programmes such as the strengthening the relative rights of people working the land programme, also known as the 50-50 programme.
sot: ha re tswela pele, mmuso o tla tswelapele ka ho kenya tshebetsong mananeo a mang a kang lenaneo la matlafatso ya ditokelo tsa bohlokwa tsa batho ba sebetsanang le mobu, le boelang le tsejwa ka hore ke lenaneo la 50-50. lenaneong lena, basebetsi ba mapolasing ba ipopa ho ba setheo sa molao mme ha ba le mmoho le monga polasi, khamphane e ntjha e a thewa mme basebetsi le monga polasi e ba beng ba polasi ka kopanelo.

eng: in this programme, the farm workers join together into a legal entity and together with the farm owner, a new company is established and the workers and the owner become joint owners.
sot: ho fihlela kajeno, ditshisinyo tse 13 di se di ananetswe, e leng se folang molemo malapa a badudi ba mapolasing a 921 ka boleng ba r631 milione.

eng: we applaud farmers and farm workers for this innovation.
sot: re thoholetsa borapolasi le basebetsi ba mapolasing ka kgato ena.

eng: most importantly, we appeal to land claimants to accept land instead of financial compensation.
sot: ya bohlokwahlokwa, re ipiletsa ho batseki ba mobu hore ba amohele mobu ho e na le ditlhapiso tsa ditjhelete.

eng: over 90% of claims are currently settled through financial compensation, which does not help the process at all.
sot: ha jwale ke ditseko tse kahodimo ho 90% tse lokiswang ka ditlhapiso tsa ditjhelete, e leng ntho e sa thuseng ho hang mosebetsing ona.

eng: it perpetuates dispossession.
sot: e kgothaletsa taba ya ho hloka mobu.

eng: it also undermines economic empowerment.
sot: e boela e hatikela matlafatso moruong.

eng: government has committed itself to support black smallholder farmers.
sot: mmuso o ikitlaeditse ho tshehetsa borapolasi ba ntseng ba hola ba batsho.

eng: i received a memorandum from the african farmers association of south africa who says that the year 2017 must be the year of the commercialisation of the black smallholder farmers.
sot: ke amohetse memorandamo o tswang mokgatlong wa aforika borwa wa borapolasi ba maaforika, o reng selemo sa 2017 se tlameha ho ba selemo sa ho kenngwa kgwebong ha borapolasi ba batsho ba ntseng ba hola.

eng: indeed, government will implement a commercialisation support programme for 450 black smallholder farmers.
sot: ka sebele, mmuso o tla kenya tshebetsong lenaneo la tshehetso ya ho kenngwa kgwebong ha borapolasi ba batsho ba ntseng ba hola ba 450. re kgothaletsa basadi ba bangata ho nahana ka ho kena temong.

eng: i have, as a special guest today, the 2016 female farmer of the year, vanecia janse from koukamma municipality in the eastern cape.
sot: ke na rapolasi wa selemo sa 2016 ya motshehadi, e le moeti wa ka ya kgethehileng kajeno, vanecia janse wa masepaleng wa koukamma kapa botjhabela.

eng: compatriots,our farmers went through a difficult period last year because of the drought.
sot: baheso,borapolasi ba rona ba fetile mathateng nakong ya selemo se fetileng ka lebaka la komello.

eng: to date, an estimated amount of r2.5 billion was made available for the provision of livestock feed, water infrastructure, drilling, equipping and refurbishment of boreholes, auction sales and other interventions.
sot: ho fihlela kajeno, tjhelete e lekanyetswang ho r2.5 bilione e ile ya ntshuwa bakeng sa phano ya furu ya diphoofolo, meralo ya motheo ya metsi, ho tjheka, phano ya disebedisuwa le ntjhafatso ya didiba tse tjhekilweng, fantisi le mehato e meng ya bokenadipakeng.

eng: furthermore, the industrial development corporation and the land bank availed funding of about r500 million to distressed farmers to manage their credit facilities and support with soft loans.
sot: ho feta moo, koporasi ya ntshetsopele ya diindasteri (idc) le banka ya tsa mobu di neelane ka tjhelete e kaalo ka r500 milione ho borapolasi ba thefulehileng, ho tsitsisa dikoloto tsa bona esita le tshehetso ya dikadimo tse fokolang tsa ditjhelete.

eng: compatriots,president oliver reginald tambo was a champion of women’s rights.
sot: baheso,mopresidente oliver reginald tambo e ne e le molwanedi wa ditokelo tsa basadi.

eng: we will continue to mainstream the empowerment of women in all government programmes.
sot: re tla tswelapele ho bea ka sehloohong matlafatso ya basadi mananeong ohle a mmuso.

eng: government will continue to prioritise women’s access to economic opportunities and, in particular, to business financing and credit.
sot: mmuso o tla tswelapele ho bea ka sehloohong phihlello ya basadi menyetleng ya moruo, haholoholo tjheleteng ya ho etsa kgwebo esita le ho fumana sekoloto.

eng: this is the freedom that heroines of the struggle such as the late dora tamana of gugulethu, here in cape town, fought for.
sot: ena ke tokoloho eo bahale ba ntwa ba kang mofu dora tamana wa gugulethu, kwano motse kapa, ba e lwanetseng.

eng: i am pleased to have her son, mongezi tamana, as a guest today.
sot: ke motlotlo ho ba le mora wa hae, mongezi tamana, e le moeti kajeno.

eng: compatriots,in december 2015, university students voiced their concerns about the cost of higher education.
sot: baheso,ka tshitwe 2015, baithuti ba diyunivesithi ba ile ba hlahisa dingongoreho tsa bona ka ditjeo tsa thuto e phahameng.

eng: they correctly pointed out that accumulated debt and fast rising fees were making it harder and harder for those who come from less-privileged households to enter and stay within the education system until they complete their studies.
sot: ba bontshitse ka nepo hore dikoloto tseo ba seng ba na le tsona esita le ditefello tsa thuto tse nyolohang ka potlako di thatafatsa maemo haholo bakeng sa bao ba tswang malapeng a kojwana di mahetleng hore ba kene ba be ba tsepame kahara thuto ho fihlela ba phethela dithuto tsa bona.

eng: it is for this reason that when university students expressed genuine concerns about being excluded from universities, our caring government responded appropriately by taking over the responsibility to pay the fee increase for the 2016 academic year.
sot: ke ka lebaka lena e leng hore ha baithuti ba diyunivesithi ba hlahisa dingongoreho tsa bonnete ka ho qhelelwa ka thoko diyunivesithing, mmuso wa rona o tsotellang o ile wa arabela ka bokgabane ka hore o nke boikarabelo ba ho lefa tjhelete e nyollotsweng bakeng sa selemo sa dithuto sa 2016. mmuso o boetse wa lefa dikoloto tsohle tse kolotwang ke baithuti ba lekgotla la naha la dithuso tsa ditjhelete tsa baithuti (nsfas) mme wa nanabetsa phumano lenaneng la baithuti le hodimo le ho feta pele.

eng: government also settled all debt owed by the national student financial aid scheme (nsfas) students and extended the coverage to larger numbers of students than ever before.
sot: nakong ya ho tekwa ha leanong la ditekanyetso tsa nako e bohareng (mtbps) la 2016, mmuso wa rona o tsebisitse ka mehato e ekeditsweng e reretsweng ho etsa hore thuto e fihlellehe baithuting ba bangata ba tswang malapeng a basebetsi.

eng: at the time of tabling the 2016 medium term budget policy statement, our government announced additional measures aimed at making higher education accessible to more students from working class families.
sot: mmuso o se o fane ka ditjhelete tsa ho netefatsa hore ha ho moithuti eo e bang tjhelete yohle e kenang lapeng labo ha e fete r600 000 ka selemo, ya tla tobana le nyollo ya ditefello diyunivesithing le dikholetjhe tsa thuto le thupello ya mosebetsi wa setegeniki (tvet) ka 2017. baithuti bohle ba lokelwang ke nsfas ba seng ba amohetswe diyunivesithi le dikholejeng, ba tla thuswa ka tjhelete.

eng: government has provided funds to ensure that no student whose combined family income is up to r600 000 per annum will face fee increases at universities and technical vocational education and training (tvet) colleges for 2017. all students who qualify for nsfas and whom have been accepted by universities and tvet colleges, will be funded.
sot: dikoloto tsa diyunivesithi tsa baithuti ba lokelwang ke nsfas bakeng sa dilemo tsa dithuto tsa 2013, 2014 le 2015 di se di rarollotswe.

eng: in total, government has reprioritised r32 billion within government baselines to support higher education.
sot: ka kakaretso, mmuso o boetse o beile ka sehloohong r32 bilione kahara manane a mmuso ho tshehetsa thuto e phahameng.

eng: we are ensuring that our deserving students can study without fearing that past debts will prevent them from finishing their studies.
sot: re a netefatsa hore baithuti ba rona ba lokelwang, ba ka ithuta ntle le tshabo ya hore dikoloto tsa nako e fetileng di tla ba thibela ho phethela dithuto tsa bona.

eng: in the remaining years of this administration, our policies will respond directly to the following concerns that the students have placed firmly on the table:firstly, the students have expressed concern that the nsfas threshold of r122 000 is too low.
sot: dilemong tse setseng tsa botsamaisi bona, maano a rona a tla arabela ka kotloloho dingongorehong tse latelang tseo baithuti ba re teketseng tsona:ya pele, baithuti ba hlahisitse ngongoreho ya hore sekepele sa nsfas sa r122 000 se tlase haholo.

eng: we will have to look into this matter with the view to raising the threshold on a phased basis in the period ahead.
sot: re tlameha ho shebisisa taba ena ka mohopolo wa ho nyolla sekepele ka mekgahlelo nakong e tlang.

eng: secondly, the students have pointed out that the full cost of study at some universities is higher than the subsidy that nsfas provides.
sot: ya bobedi, baithuti ba bontshitse hore ditjeo tsa dithuto tsohle diyunivesithing tse ding e kahodimo ho tlatseletso eo nsfas e fanang ka yona.

eng: as a result, nsfas students who study at some universities that charge higher fees end up accumulating debt.
sot: ka lebaka leo, baithuti ba nsfas ba ithutang diyunivesithing tse ding tse lefisang ditefiso tse hodimo, ba qetela ba na le sekoloto.

eng: our government-initiated processes are already looking at this issue too.
sot: matsholo a thakgotsweng ke mmuso wa rona le wona a se a ntse a e shebisisa taba ena.

eng: honourable members and fellow south africans, students and their parents should understand that the needs for services such as water, sanitation, early childhood development and good public transport also have to be addressed, alongside access to quality higher education and training.
sot: ditho tse hlomphehang le maaforika borwa a heso, baithuti le batswadi ba bona ba tshwanela ho utlwisisa hore ditlhoko tsa ditshebeletso tse kang tsa metsi, tlhwekiso ya dikgwerekgwere, kgodiso ya bana ba banyane (ecd) le dipalangwang tse ntle tsa setjhaba le tsona di tshwanela ho rarollwa, hammoho le phihlello ya thuto e phahameng le thupelo tsa boleng.

eng: but our commitment to finding sustainable solutions to the funding of the social wage in general, and education, in particular, is unwavering.
sot: empa boikitlaetso ba rona ba ho fumana ditharollo tsa nako e telele tsa ho kenya tjhelete mathateng a setjhaba ka kakaretso, le thutong, haholoholo, ha bo sisinngwe.

eng: as the processes that we have set in motion draw to a close, such as the heher commission, the ministerial task team, broader engagements with students, university and tvet leadership and civil society, we will find resources to give expression to our policies.
sot: jwalokaha matsholo ao re a thakgotseng a le mathuleng a ho fela, jwaloka khomishene ya heher, sehlopha sa tshebetso sa matona, dipuisano tse batsi le baithuti, boetapele ba diyunivesithi le thuto le thupelo ya mesebetsi ya matsoho ya setekgeniki le setjhaba, re tla fumana mehlodi ya ho fa maano a rona meelelo.

eng: i invite all stakeholders to participate in the processes that are underway so that no view is not heard.
sot: ke ipiletsa ho bohle ba amehang ho ba le seabo matsholong a seng a le motjheng, ho etsetsa hore ho se ke ha eba le maikutlo a sa sekehelweng tsebe.

eng: no great idea should be excluded.
sot: ha ho maikutlo a matle a tshwanelang ho kotelwa.

eng: as soon as the broadest sections of our society agree on what to do, our government will take steps to reprioritise resources to implement it on a phased basis.
sot: hang ha dikarolo tse kgolo tsa setjhaba di dumellana ka hore na ho etswe eng, mmuso wa rona o tla nka dikgato tsa ho boela o bea ka sehloohong mehlodi ya ho di kenya tshebetsong ka mekgahlelo.

eng: let us engage to identify the most pressing needs and allocate our limited resources accordingly.
sot: ha re buisaneng re tsebe ho hlwaya ditlhoko tseo e leng tsona tsa bohlokwahlokwa mme re anetse mehlodi ya rona e fokolang ka nepo.

eng: let us build our self-reliance and move forward in the spirit of unity.
sot: ha re aheng boitshepo ba rona mme re hahamalle pele ka moya wa kopano.

eng: compatriots,the fight against crime is an apex priority.
sot: baheso,twantsho ya ditlolo tsa molao ke ntho ya bohlokwa e ka sehloohong.

eng: the police will increase visible policing, building on the successful pattern of deployments utilised during the safer festive season campaign.
sot: sepolesa se tla eketsa lenane la mapolesa a bonahalang ditseleng, ho sehelwa thebe hodima mokgwa wa katleho ya ho bewa dibakeng tse fapaneng e sebedisitsweng nakong ya letsholo la monyaka wa mafelo a selemo a bolokehileng.

eng: they will also utilise certain specialised capabilities, such as the tactical response teams and national intervention units, to assist in addressing problematic high-crime areas.
sot: ba tla boela ba sebedisa bokgoni bo bong bo kgethehileng, bo kang ba dihlopha tse phahamelang mapoqo le diyuniti tsa naha tsa bokenadipakeng, ho thusa ho rarolla mathata a dibaka tse nang le ditlolo tse hodimo tsa molao.

eng: we received a message from soshanguve last week that crime is rife in block l and that hijackings and robberies are high.
sot: re fumane molaetsa o tswang soshanguve bekeng e fetileng, wa hore ditlolo tsa molao di jele setsi tulong ya block l le hore ho kwetela le ditlatlapo di hodimo.

eng: it is such communities that need to build stronger partnerships with the police to ensure that criminals do not prey on residents.
sot: ke dibaka tse jwalo tse hlokang ho aha dilekane tse matla le sepolesa, ho netefatsa hore batlodi ba molao ha ba ithuisa ka baahi.

eng: other measures to fight crime nationally will include the establishment of specialised units, focusing on drug-related crime, taxi violence and firearms and the enhanced utilisation of investigative aids such as forensic leads.
sot: mehato e meng ya ho lwantsha ditlolo tsa molao naha ka bophara e akga ho thewa ha diyuniti tse kgethehileng, ho tsepamisitswe maikutlo ditlolong tsa molao tse amanang le dithethefatsi, merusu ya ditekesing le dithunya esita le tshebediso e ntlafaditsweng ya dithusetsi tsa ho batlisisa tse kang lesedi la forensiki.

eng: the police will also enhance the utilisation of the dna database in the identification of suspects.
sot: sepolesa se tla boela se ntlafatsa tshebediso ya databeisi ya dna tlhwayong ya babelaellwa.

eng: we urge the public to work with the police to ensure safer communities.
sot: re kopa setjhaba hore se sebedisane le sepolesa ho netefatsa hore dibaka di a bolokeha.

eng: compatriots,we welcome the decline in rhino poaching incidents since october 2015, which is for the first time in a decade.
sot: baheso,re amohela phokotseho ya diketsahalo tsa ho utsuwa ha ditshukudu haesale ho tloha ka mphalane 2015, e leng kgetlo la pele nakong ya dilemoshome.

eng: this arises from intensive joint operations by law-enforcement agencies.
sot: sena se etsahetse ka lebaka la ditshebetso tse matla tsa kopanelo tsa diakgente tsa molao.

eng: compatriots,one of the strategies of fighting crime is to ensure that those who are released from prison do not commit crime again.
sot: baheso,a mang a mawa a ho lwantsha ditlolo tsa molao ke ho netefatsa hore bao ba lokollwang tjhankaneng ha ba etse ditlolo tsa molao hape.

eng: the department of correctional services continues to work hard to turn prisons into correctional centres through offering various services.
sot: lefapha la ditshebeletso tsa tshokollo ya batshwaruwa le sebetsa ka thata ho fetola ditjhankana hore e be ditsi tsa tshokollo ka ho fana ka ditshebeletso tse fapaneng.

eng: as a result, compliance levels with parole and probation conditions have improved to reach a historic mark of 98%.
sot: kahoo, maemo a boikamahanyo le parola esita le maemo a ho bewa tekong di ntlafetse ho ya fihla matshwaong a etsang nalane a 98%.

eng: the country has also made good progress in reducing the numbers of children in correctional centres.
sot: naha e boetse ya etsa kgatelopele e ntle ho fokotseng manane a bana ba ditsing tsa tshokollo.

eng: compatriots,the promotion of access to justice was given added meaning last year when the high court division in limpopo was opened in november.
sot: baheso,ho phahamiswa ha phihlello tokeng ho ile ha fuwa moelelo o ekeditsweng ngwahola ha karolo ya lekgotla le phahameng la dinyewe la limpopo le ne le bulwa ka pudungwana.

eng: the mpumalanga high court will be completed during this financial year.
sot: lekgotla le phahameng la dinyewe la mpumalanga le tla phethelwa nakong ya selemo sena sa ditjhelete.

eng: the coming into operation of these two high courts means that we have now realised the goal of a high court in every province of the country.
sot: ho sebetsa ha makgotla ana a mabedi a phahameng a dinyewe ho bolela hore jwale re hlokometse sepheo sa lekgotla le phahameng la dinyewe profenseng e nngwe le e nngwe naheng ena.

eng: compatriots,the fight against corruption continues.
sot: baheso,twantsho ya bonyofonyofo e tswelapele.

eng: within the national prosecuting authority, the asset forfeiture unit completed 389 forfeiture cases to the value of r349 million.
sot: kahare ho lekgotla la botjhutjhisi ba naha, yuniti ya kgapo ya thepa e phethetse dinyewe tsa kgapo tse 389 tsa boleng ba r349 milione.

eng: they obtained 326 freezing orders to the value of r779 million.
sot: ba fumane ditumello tsa ho hakuretsa thepa tse 326 tsa boleng ba r779 milione.

eng: a total of r13 million was recovered in cases where government officials were involved in corruption and other related offences in the past year.
sot: palo yohle ya r13 milione e ile ya kgutliswa dinyeweng tseo ho tsona bahlanka ba mmuso ba neng ba ameha bonyofonyofong le ditlolong tse ding nakong ya selemo se fetileng.

eng: compatriots,oliver tambo set the tone for the country’s foreign policy as early as 1977 when addressing the first congress of the angolan ruling party mpla that:“we seek to live in peace with our neighbours and the peoples of the world in conditions of equality, mutual respect and equal advantage”.
sot: baheso,oliver tambo o ile a etsa mohlala o motle wa leano la naha la bolata kgale kwana ka 1977 ha a ne a tshetleha puo sebokeng sa pele sa mokga o busang wa angola mpla ka ho re:“re batla ho phela ka kgotso le baahisane ba rona le batho ba lefatshe lohle maemong a tekano, tlhomphano le menyetla e lekanang”.

eng: south africa is honoured to chair the southern african development community (sadc) starting from august 2017. we will utilise our tenure to fast track the implementation of the sadc industrial strategy.
sot: aforika borwa e tlotlehile ka bodulasetulo ba ntshetsopele ya dibaka tsa borwa ba aforika (sadc) ho tloha ka phato ya 2017. re tla sebedisa sehla sa rona ho akofisa ho kenngwa tshebetsong ha lewa la diindasteri la sadc.

eng: we are accelerating the integration agenda through the implementation of sadc-comesa-east african community free trade area.
sot: re potlakisa lenanetsamaiso la momahanyo ka ho kenngwa tshebetsong ha sadc-comesa-sebaka sa kgwebisano e lokolohileng setjhabeng sa botjhabela ba aforika.

eng: we will continue with our involvement in our mediation efforts, peacekeeping operations, and peace-making initiatives in lesotho, democratic republic of congo, burundi, mozambique, south sudan, somalia and libya.
sot: re tla tswelapele ka ho kena ha rona matsapeng a bonamodi, ditshebetso tsa ho boloka kgotso, le dikgato tsa ho tlisa kgotso lesotho, democratic republic of congo, burundi, mozambique, sudan borwa, somalia le libya.

eng: the south african national defence force represents the country well in the peacekeeping missions.
sot: lebotho la sesole sa naha la aforika borwa le emetse naha ka bokgabane matsholong a ho boloka kgotso.

eng: furthermore, trade with our traditional partners in the west remains a significant contributor to our economy.
sot: ho feta moo, kgwebisano le balekane ba rona ba tlwaelehileng ka bophirimela e dula e le monyehedi wa bohlokwa moruong wa rona.

eng: we will continue to partner with the united states and work together on issues of mutual interest such as the full renewal of african growth and opportunity act.
sot: re tla tswelapele ka bolekane le amerika mme re sebetse mmoho dinthong tse thusang mahlakoreng ohle tse kang ntjhafatso e tletseng ya molao wa kgolo le menyetla ya aforika (agoa).

eng: we value our relationship with the prc.
sot: re se nkela hloohong selekane sa rona le china.

eng: china is one of south africa’s most important and key strategic partners.
sot: china ke e nngwe ya balekane ba bohlokwahlokwa ebile e le ba lewa la bohlokwa ba aforika borwa.

eng: we recognise the prc ‘as the sole government and authority representing the whole of china’.
sot: re ananela china e le ona feela mmuso le lekgotla le emetseng china ka kakaretso ’.

eng: south africa reiterates its position and commitment to the ‘one china policy’ and we consider taiwan as an integral part of the prc.
sot: aforika borwa e boela e tiisa boemo ba yona le boikitlaetso ba yona ho ‘sebetsa le naha ya china jwaloka moetapele wa dinaha tsa china’ mme re nka taiwan e le karolo ya bohlokwa ya china.

eng: at continental partnership level, the joint africa-european union (eu) strategy remains an important long-term framework for continued cooperation.
sot: boemong ba bolekane ba dikontinente, lewa la kopanelo la kopano ya aforika-yuropa (eu) le dula e le moralo wa bohlokwa wa nako e telele bakeng sa tshebedisanommoho e tswelang pele.

eng: the economic partnership agreement with the eu came into force in september 2016, thus providing new market access opportunities for south african products.
sot: tumellano ya selekane sa moruo le eu e qadile ho sebetsa ka loetse 2016, yaba e fana ka menyetla e metjha ya phihlello mebarakeng bakeng sa dihlahiswa tsa aforika borwa.

eng: almost all south african products, about 99% will have preferential market access in the eu.
sot: e batla e le dihlahiswa tsohle tsa aforika borwa, tse ka bang 99% di tla ba le phihlello e qollotsweng mebarakeng ya eu.

eng: about 96% of the products will enter the eu market without being subjected to customs duties or quantitative restrictions.
sot: tse ka bang 96% tsa dihlahiswa di tla mebarakeng ya eu ntle le hore di ye ditefellong tsa lekgetho kapa moqeqekong wa dithibelo.

eng: the southern african customs union mercosur preferential trade agreement has also entered into force, providing preferential access to over 1 000 tariff lines.
sot: tumellano ya kgwebisano ya kopano ya ditefello tsa lekgetho ya borwa ba aforika e qollotsweng ya mercusor le yona e kene tshebetsong, e fana ka phihlello e qollotsweng dikepeleng tse fetang 1 000. ena ke tumellano e phahamisang kgwebisano ya borwa-borwa.

eng: this is an agreement that promotes south-south trade.
sot: selekane sa rona sa tshebedisanommoho le mabatowa a mang se bea ditholwana.

eng: our cooperative partnerships with other regions are bearing fruits.
sot: banka e ntjha ya ntshetsopele ya brics e ngodisitswe kgatelopele e kgothatsang.

eng: the brics new development bank has recorded encouraging progress.
sot: re amohela dihlooho tsa naha tsa goa brics le qeto ya mmuso ya ho thea akgente e sekasekang maemo ya brics, ho etsetsa hore re tle re thusane ka ho hlahloba metjha ya rona ya moruo.

eng: we are also pleased with agreements with our brics partners in the field of agriculture.
sot: re boetse re motlotlo ka ditumellano le balekane ba rona ba brics lekaleng la temothuo.

eng: we will implement off take agreements on the export of pulses, mangos and pork to india.
sot: re tla kenya tshebetsong ditumellano tsa ho thakgoha ho diyantle tsa dierekisi tsa pulse, dimango le nama ya kolobe ho ya india.

eng: we will also export 20 000 tons of beef to china per year for a period of 10 years.
sot: re tla boela re isa kantle ditone tse 20 000 tsa nama ya kgomo ho ya china ka selemo ka nako ya dilemo tse 10. re tla tswelapele ho sututsa tlhabollo ya mekgwatsamaiso ya matjhaba hobane maemo a renang jwale a hatikela bokgoni ba dinaha tse thuthuang hore di kenye letsoho di be di fole molemo ka mokgwa o utlwahalang.

eng: this year marks the 50th anniversary of the occupation of palestine.
sot: monongwaha re tshwaya sehopotso sa bo50 sa ho dulwa ka sheshe ha palestine.

eng: the expansion of israeli settlements undermines global efforts aimed at realising the two state solution and the oslo accord.
sot: katoloso ya bodulo ba isiraele e hatikela matsapa a lefatshe lohle a reretsweng ho fumana tharollo ya dinaha tsena tse pedi esita le tumellano ya oslo.

eng: we wish to reiterate our support for the palestinian course.
sot: re batla ho thasisetsa tshehetso ya rona ya malebaleba a palestina.

eng: similarly, we hope that the readmission of morocco to the african union should serve as a catalyst to resolve the western sahara issue.
sot: ka ho tshwanang, re tshepa hore kamohelobotjha ya morocco kopanong ya aforika (au) e tshwanela ho sebetsa jwaloka sesebediswa sa ho rarolla taba ya bophirimela ba sahara.

eng: let me add that south africa will use armed forces day on 21 february 2017 to mark the centenary commemorations of the tragic sinking of the ss mendi, which left 646 soldiers dead in 1917. compatriots,the constitution accords equal rights and dignity to all south africans.
sot: e re ke eketse ka hore aforika borwa e tla sebedisa letsatsi la mabotho a hlometseng ka la 21 hlakola 2017 ho tshwaya meketjana ya dilemokgolo tsa koduwa ya ho teba ha sekepe sa ss mendi, se siileng masole a 646 a shwele ka 1917. baheso,molaotheo o fana ka ditokelo tse lekanang le seriti ho maaforika borwa ohle.

eng: the united nations proclaimed 13 june as international albinism awareness day.
sot: matjhaba a kopaneng (un) a tsebisitse mohla la 13 phuptjane e le letsatsi la matjhaba la tlhokomediso ya boalbino.

eng: we should use this day to raise awareness and eliminate the discrimination or harm that compatriots with albinism are subjected to in some areas.
sot: re tshwanela ho sebedisa letsatsi lena ho etsa tlhokomediso le ho fedisa kgethollo kapa kotsi eo baheso ba nang le boalbino ba teanang le yona dibakeng tse ding.

eng: speaker of the national assembly (na), ms baleka mbete,chairperson of the national council of provinces (ncop), ms thandi modise,deputy speaker of the na and deputy chairperson of the ncop,former president thabo mbeki,former deputy president fw de klerk,chief justice mogoeng mogoeng and all esteemed members of the judiciary,ministers and deputy ministers,premiers and speakers of provincial legislatures,chairperson of south african local government association and all executive mayors present,the heads of chapter 9 institutions,chairperson of the national house of traditional leaders,leaders of faith-based organisations,former speaker dr frene ginwala,former speaker mr max sisulu,invited guests,veterans of the struggle for liberation,members of the diplomatic corps,honourable members,fellow south africans.
sot: motsamaisi wa dipuisano wa seboka sa naha (na), mofumahadi baleka mbete,modulasetulo wa lekgotla la naha la diporofense (ncop), mofumahadi thandi modise,motlatsi wa motsamaisi wa dipuisano wa na le motlatsi wa modulasetulo wa ncop,moporesidente wa mehleng thabo mbeki,moporesidente wa mehleng fw de klerk,moahlodi e moholo mogoeng mogoeng le ditho tsohle tse kgabane tsa boahlodi,matona le batlatsi ba matona,ditonakgolo le batsamaisi ba dipuisano ba makgotla a ketsamolao a diporofense,modulasetulo wa lekgotla la mmuso wa dibaka la aforika borwa le bomajoro bohle ba phethahatso ba teng,dihlooho tsa ditheo tse tshehetsang molaotheo,modulasetulo wa ntlo ya naha ya baetapele ba setso,baetapele ba mekgatlo ya ditumelo tse fapaneng,motsamaisi wa dipuisano wa mehleng ngaka frene ginwala,motsamaisi wa dipuisano wa mehleng monghadi max sisulu,baeti ba teng,mekaubere ya ntwa ya tokoloho,ditho tsa bodiplomate,ditho tse hlomphehang,maaforika borwa a heso.

eng: it is for me a great honour and privilege to have the opportunity to deliver this state of the nation address (sona).
sot: ke tlotla e kgolo ho nna ho fumana sebaka le monyetla wa ho tshetleha puo ena ya boemo ba naha (sona).

eng: this address should have been delivered last week, but was delayed so that we could properly and carefully manage issues of political transition.
sot: puo ena e ne e lokela ho tekwa bekeng e fetileng, empa e ile ya diehiswa ho etsetsa hore re kgone ho laola dintlha tsa neeletsano ya sepolotiki ka nepo le ka hloko.

eng: i wish to thank honourable members and the people of south africa for their patience and forbearance.
sot: ke lakatsa ho leboha ditho tse hlomphehang le batho ba aforika borwa ka mamello le boikokobetso ba bona.

eng: i also wish to extend a word of gratitude to former president jacob zuma for the manner in which he approached this difficult and sensitive process.
sot: hape ke lakatsa ho fetisetsa lentswe la teboho ho moporesidente wa mehleng jacob zuma ka mokgwa oo a ileng a sebetsana le tsamaiso ena e boima ebile e le hlokolosi.

eng: i wish to thank him for his service to the nation during his two terms as president of the republic, during which the country made significant progress in several areas of development.
sot: ke lakatsa ho mo leboha ka tshebeletso ya hae setjhabeng nakong ya dihla tsa hae tse pedi tseo e bileng moporesidente wa riphaboliki ka tsona, e leng nakong eo naha e entseng kgatelopele e bonahalang dinthong tse ngata tsa ntshetsopele.

eng: i have spoken to president zuma yesterday and he wished us well for the holding of this sona.
sot: ke buile le moporesidente jacob zuma maobane mme o re lakaleditse mahlohonolo bakeng sa sona ena.

eng: fellow south africans,in just over 150 days from now, the peoples of the world will unite in celebrating the 100th anniversary of the birth of nelson rolihlahla mandela.
sot: maaforika borwa a heso,ka matsatsi a ka hodima a 150 ho tloha jwale, batho ba lefatshe ba tla kopana ketekeng sehopotso sa selemo sa bo-100 sa tswalo ya nelson rolihlahla mandela.

eng: it is a day on which we, as south africans, will remember the life of one of the most remarkable leaders this country and this continent – and indeed, the world – has known.
sot: ke letsatsi leo ka lona rona, re le maafrika borwa, re tla hopola bophelo ba e mong wa baetapele ba kileng ba babatseha ka ho fetisisa bao naha ena le kontinente – bonneteng, eo lefatshe – le kileng la mo tseba.

eng: we will have an opportunity to recount madiba’s long walk to freedom, his wisdom, his unfailing humility, his abiding compassion and his essential integrity.
sot: re tla ba le monyetla wa ho hetla morao leetong la madiba le letelele la tokoloho, bohlale ba hae, boikokobetso bo sa thekeseleng, kutlwelobohloko le botshepehi ba hae bo batlehang.

eng: we have dedicated this year 2018 to his memory and we will devote our every action, every effort, and every utterance to the realisation of his vision of a democratic, just and equitable society.
sot: re nyehetse selemo sena sa 2018 ho mo hopoleng mme re tla tela tsohle, re etse mekutu yohle, esita le ntho e nngwe le enngwe eo re e buang, hore re fihlelle tjhebelopele ya hae ya setjhaba sa demokerasi, sa toka le tekano.

eng: guided by his example, we will use this year to reinforce our commitment to ethical behaviour and ethical leadership.
sot: re tataiswa ke mohlala wa hae, re tla sebedisa selemo sena ho matlafatsa boitlamo ba rona boitshwaro bo botle le boetapele bo botle.

eng: in celebrating the centenary of nelson mandela we are not merely honouring the past, we are building the future and particularly the future that mandela envisaged.
sot: ha re keteka dilemo tse lekgolo tsa nelson mandela, ha re hlomphe tse fetileng feela, empa re aha bokamoso haholoholo bokamoso boo mandela a neng a bo labalabela.

eng: we are continuing the long walk he began, to build a society in which all may be free, in which all may be equal before the law and in which all may share in the wealth of our land and have a better life.
sot: re tswelapele ka leeto le letelele leo a le qadileng, ho aha setjhaba moo bohle ba ka lokolohang, moo bohle ba ka lekanang ka pela molao ebile e le moo bohle ba ka arolelanang maruo a naha ya rona mme re be le bophelo bo betere.

eng: we are building a country where a person’s prospects are determined by their own initiative and hard work, and not by the colour of their skin, place of birth, gender, language or income of their parents.
sot: re aha naha moo makgabane a motho a lekanngwang ho ya ka boikitlaetso ba hae esita le ho sebetsa ka thata, e seng ho ya ka mmala wa letlalo la hae, moo a hlahetseng teng, bong, puo kapa lekeno la batswadi ba hae.

eng: ek wil dit nou mooi in afrikaans se: ons bou ’n land waarin ’n persoon se vooruitsigte bepaal word deur sy eie inisiatief en harde werk, en nie deur sy velkleur, geboorteplek, geslag, taal of inkomste van hulle ouers nie.
sot: ek wil dit ook in afrikaans se:ons bou ’n land waarin ’n persoon se vooruitsigte bepaal word deur sy eie inisiatief en harde werk, en nie deur sy velkleur, geboorteplek, geslag, taal of sy ouers se inkomste nie.. monongwaha re boela re keteka dilemo tse lekgolo tsa mohale e mong wa ntwa ya rona, albertina nontsikelelo sisulu.

eng: this year, we also celebrate the centenary of another giant of our struggle, albertina nontsikelelo sisulu.
sot: ka bophelo ba hae bo babatsehang le nyehelo e kgabane, o hlalositse hore na ho ba molwanedi wa tokoloho ke ho ba eng, moetapele eo e leng mosebeletsi wa batho ya ikitlaeditseng a bile a na le boitshwaro bo botle.

eng: through her remarkable life and outstanding contribution, she defined what it means to be a freedom fighter, a leader and a diligent and disciplined servant of the people.
sot: ka boetapele ba hae, e bile lehokela la motheo dipakeng tsa tokoloho ya naha le tokoloho ya bong.

eng: through her leadership, she embodied the fundamental link between national liberation and gender emancipation.
sot: ha re tshwaya dilemo tsa hae tse lekgolo, re tiisa botjha hore ha ho tokoloho e ka phethahalang ebile ha ho setjhaba se ka lokolohang ho fihlela basadi ba sona ba lokolohile.

eng: as we mark her centenary, we reaffirm that no liberation can be complete and no nation can be free until its women are free.
sot: re tlotla mora enwa, nelson rolihlahla mandela le moradi enwa eo e leng letswallwa la aforika, albertina sisulu, selemong sa diphetoho, selemong sa ntjhafatso, selemong sa tshepo.

eng: we honour them not only in word, but, more importantly, in direct action towards the achievement of their shared vision of a better society.
sot: ha re ba tlotle feela ka molomo, empa, haholoholo, ka mesebetsi e otlolohileng e lebisang phihlellong ya tjhadimo ya bona e tshwanang ya setjhaba se betere.

eng: we should honour madiba by putting behind us the era of discord, disunity and disillusionment.
sot: re lokela ho tlotla madiba ka ho lebala ka mehla ya diqhwebeshano, dikarohano le ho se tshepane.

eng: we should put behind us the era of diminishing trust in public institutions and weakened confidence in our country’s leaders.
sot: re lokela ho lebala ka mehla ya ho nyotobela ha ditheo tsa setjhaba esita le boitshepo bo thefulehileng ba baetapele ba naha ya rona.

eng: we should put all the negativity that has dogged our country behind us because a new dawn is upon us and a wonderful dawn has arrived.
sot: re lokela ho lebala ka tse mpe tseo e leng kgale di tshwenya naha ya rona hobane mahlasedi a matjha a re tjhabetse ebile mahlasedi a babatsehang a fihlile.

eng: it is a new dawn that is inspired by our collective memory of nelson mandela and the changes that are unfolding.
sot: ke mahlasedi a matjha a hahlametsweng ke menahano ya rona e kopanetsweng ya nelson mandela le diphetoho tse utollohang.

eng: as we rid our minds of all negativity, we should reaffirm our belief that south africa belongs to all who live in it.
sot: ha re ntse re tlhotlhora tsohle tse mpe dikellong tsa rona, re lokela ho tiisa botjha tumelo ya rona ya hore aforika borwa ke ya bohle ba phelang ho yona.

eng: there are 57 million of us, each with different histories, languages, cultures, experiences, views and interests.
sot: re 57 milione, e mong le e mong ka dinalane tse fapaneng, dipuo, botjhaba, malebela le ditabatabelo.

eng: yet we are bound together by a common destiny that we are south africans.
sot: empa re tlamahantswe mmoho ke sepheo se le seng sa hore re maaforika borwa.

eng: for this, we owe much to our forebearers – people like pixley ka seme, charlotte maxeke and chief albert luthuli – who understood the necessity of the unity and harmony of all the people of this great land.
sot: kahoo, re lokela ho leboha baholoholo ba rona – batho ba kang pixley ka seme, charlotte maxeke le morena albert luthuli – ba neng ba utlwisisa tlhokeho ya momahano le selekane sa batho bohle ba naha ena e kgabane.

eng: we are a nation at one.
sot: re setjhaba se le seng.

eng: we are one people, committed to work together to find jobs for our youth.
sot: re batho ba le bang, ba ikemiseditseng ho sebetsa mmoho ho fumanela batjha mesebetsi.

eng: to build factories and roads, houses, and clinics.
sot: ho aha difeme le mebila, matlo, le ditliliniki.

eng: to prepare our children for a world of change and progress.
sot: ho hlophisetsa bana ba rona ho lokela lefatshe la diphetoho le kgatelopele.

eng: to build cities and towns where families may be safe, productive, and content.
sot: ho aha ditoropo tse kgolo le ditorotswana moo malapa a ka bolokehang, a be le tshebetso, le kgotsofalo.

eng: we are determined to build a society defined by decency and integrity that does not tolerate the plunder of public resources, nor the theft by corporate criminals of the hard-earned savings of ordinary people.
sot: re ikemiseditse ho aha setjhaba se tsejwang ka tlhompho le seriti, se sa mamelleng ho utsuwa ha mehlodi ya setjhaba, kapa boshodu ba batlodi ba molao ba dikgwebo tse kgolo ba utswang dipoloko tse sebeleditsweng ka thata ke batho ba tlwaelehileng.

eng: while there are many issues on which we may differ, on these fundamental matters, we are at one.
sot: leha e le hore ho na le dintho tse ngata tseo re ka nnang ra fapana ka tsona, empa ditabeng tsena tsa bohlokwa, re ntho e le nngwe.

eng: we know that there is still a lot that divides us.
sot: re a tseba hore ho ntse ho na le boholo bo re arohanyang.

eng: we remain a highly unequal society, in which poverty and prosperity are still defined by race and gender.
sot: re dula re ntse re le setjhaba se sa lekaneng haholo, moo bofuma le monono di ntseng di hlaloswa ka morabe le bong.

eng: we have been given the responsibility as south africans to build a new nation, to confront the injustices of the past and the inequalities of the present.
sot: re fuwe boikarabelo jwaloka maaforika borwa ba ho aha setjhaba se setjha, ho tobana le ditlhokeho tsa toka tsa nako e fetileng esita le ho se lekalekane ho renang jwale.

eng: we are called upon to do so under difficult conditions.
sot: re bileditswe ho etsa sena tlasa maemo a boima.

eng: the state we are in as a nation is that while poverty declined significantly following the democratic breakthrough of 1994, we have seen reverses in recent years.
sot: boemo boo re leng ho bona re le setjhaba ke ba hore leha bofuma bo theohile haholo ho latela ho fihla ha demokerasi ka 1994, re bone re ntse fatela morao dilemong tsa moraorao tjena.

eng: poverty levels rose in 2015, unemployment has gone up and inequality has persisted.
sot: sekgahla sa bofuma se ile sa phahama ka 2015, leqeme la mesebetsi le phahame athe le ho se lekane ho ntse ho tswela pele.

eng: for several years, our economy has not grown at the pace needed to create enough jobs so that we can lift our people out of poverty.
sot: ka dilemo tse ngatanyana, moruo wa rona ha o e so hole ka sekgahla se hlokehang bakeng sa ho thea mesebetsi e lekaneng, ho etsetsa hore re kgone ho inola batho ba habo rona bofumeng.

eng: public finances have been constrained, limiting the ability of government to expand its investment in economic and social development.
sot: ditjhelete tsa setjhaba di notlilwe, mme seo se kgina bokgoni ba mmuso ba ho atolla botsetedi ba ona ntshetsopeleng ya moruo le kahisano.

eng: despite these challenging conditions, we have managed – working together – to achieve progress in improving the lives of our people.
sot: ntle le maemo ana a qholotsang, re kgonne – re sebetsa mmoho – ho fihlella kgatelopele ya ho ntlafatsa maphelo a batho ba habo rona.

eng: even under conditions of weak growth, our economy has created jobs, but not at the pace required to absorb new entrants into the labour market.
sot: esita le katlasa maemo a kgolo e fokolang, moruo wa rona o theile mesebetsi, empa e seng ka sekgahla se hlokehang sa ho kwenya ba batjha mesebetsing.

eng: this means that as we pursue higher levels of economic growth and investment, we need to take additional measures to reduce poverty and meet the needs of the unemployed in our country.
sot: sena se bolela hore ha re ntse re hahamallela maemo a hodimo a kgolo ya moruo le matsete, re lokela ho nka dikgato tsa tlatsetso ho fokotsa bofuma le ho kgahlanyetsana le ditlhoko tsa ba sa sebetseng naheng ya rona.

eng: since the start of the current parliament, our public employment programmes have created more than 3,2 million work opportunities.
sot: haesale ho tloha qalong ya palamente ya hajwale, mananeo a rona a kgiro setjhabeng a theile menyetla ya mesebetsi e kahodimo ho 3,2 milione.

eng: in the context of widespread unemployment, these opportunities continue to provide much needed income, work experience and training.
sot: ha re sheba leqeme la mesebetsi le jeleng setsi, menyetla ena e tswela pele ho fana ka lekeno le hlokehang haholo, ka melebela a mosebetsi le thupello.

eng: we have taken measures to reduce the cost of living for our people, especially for the poor.
sot: re nkile dikgato tsa ho fokotsa ditjeo tsa maemo a ho phela a batho ba habo rona, haholoholo ba kojwana di mahetleng.

eng: the cost of living has kept on rising.
sot: ditjeo tsa maemo a ho phela di ntse di hlwa mekwalaba.

eng: government’s free basic services programme currently supports more than 3,5 million indigent households.
sot: lenaneo la mmuso la ditshebeletso tsa mantlha tsa mahala hajwale le tshehetsa malapa a kojwana di mahetleng a kahodimo ho 3,5 milione.

eng: more than 17 million social grants are paid each month, benefiting nearly a third of the population.
sot: ditjhelete tsa dithuso tsa mmuso tse kahodimo ho 17 milione di a lefuwa kgwedi ka nngwe, mme di tswela molemo setjhaba se ka etsang karolo ya nngwe borarong.

eng: these social grants have elevated the lives of our people and are valued by our people.
sot: ditjhuso tsena tsa ditjhelete di phahamisitse maphelo a batho ba habo rona ebile di ananelwa ke bona batho ba habo rona.

eng: we know, however, that if we are to break the cycle of poverty, we need to educate the children of the poor.
sot: re a tseba, leha ho le jwalo, hore haeba re batla ho kgaola tepo ya bofuma, re lokela ho ruta bana ba bahloki.

eng: we have insisted that this should start in early childhood.
sot: haesale re ntse re tsitlalletse ho re sena se qale dikolong tsa dikonyana.

eng: today we have nearly a million children in early childhood development facilities.
sot: kajeno re na le bana ba ka bang milione ditsing tsa ntshetsopele ya dikolo tsa dikonyana.

eng: we are seeing improvements in the outcomes of our basic education system.
sot: re bona dintlafalo diphethong tsa tsamaiso ya rona ya thuto ya motheo.

eng: the matric pass rate increased from 60,6% in 2009 to 75,1% last year.
sot: sekgahla sa katleho dithutong tsa materiki se eketsehile ho tloha ho 60,6% ka 2009 ho ya ho 75,1% ngwahola.

eng: there are currently almost a million students enrolled in higher education, up from just over 500 000 in 1994. that represents progress.
sot: hajwale ho na le baithuti ba ka fihlang ho milione ba ngodisitsweng boemong ba thuto e phahameng, lenane le nyolohileng ho feta la kahodimonyana ho 500 000 la ka 1994. seo se bontsha kgatelopele.

eng: as we enter a new era, we are determined to build on these achievements, confront the challenges we face and accelerate progress in building a more prosperous and equitable society.
sot: ha re kena lepatlelong le letjha, re ikitlaelleditse ho aha hodima dikatleho tsena, ho lwantshana le diphephetso tse re tobileng esita le ho akofisa kgatelopele mabapi le ho aha setjhaba se tswetseng pele se bile se lekana.

eng: we have seen a moderate recovery in our economy and a broader, sustained recovery in the global economy.
sot: re bone ho hlaphohelwa ho hotlenyana moruong wa rona esita le ho hlaphohelwa ho batsi, ho tsitsitseng moruong wa lefatshe lohle.

eng: commodity prices have improved, and keep on improving and factories receiving many orders, the stock market has risen, the rand has strengthened and there are early indications that investor confidence is on the rise.
sot: ditheko tsa dihlahiswa di ntlafetse, mme di ntse di ntlafala ho ya pele athe le difeme di amohela dipeheletso tse ngata tsa ho reka dihlahiswa, mebaraka ya dithoto e phahame, ranta e matlafetse mme ho na le matshwao a hore tshepo ya batsetedi e ntse e phahama.

eng: we have taken decisive measures to address concerns about political instability and we are committed to ensure policy certainty and consistency.
sot: re nkile dikgato tse matla tsa ho rarolla matshwenyeho a amanang le tlhokeho ya botsitso dipolotiking ebile re ikemiseditse ho netefatsa boteng ba botsitso le boitjaro ba maano.

eng: there is a greater sense of optimism among our people.
sot: ho na le moya o matla wa tshepo ka hara batho ba habo rona.

eng: our people are hopeful about the future.
sot: batho ba habo rona ba na le tshepo ka bokamoso.

eng: business confidence among south african companies has improved and foreign investors are looking anew at opportunities in our country.
sot: boitshepo ba kgwebo bo ntlafetse dikhamphaneng tsa aforika borwa mme batsetedi ba melata ba shebile botjha menyetla e teng naheng ya rona.

eng: some financial institutions have identified south africa as one of the hot emerging markets for 2018. our task, as south africans, is to seize this moment of hope and renewal, and to work together to ensure that it makes a meaningful difference in the lives of our people.
sot: ditheo tse ding tsa ditjhelete di hlwaile aforika borwa e le o mong wa mebaraka e matla e runyang bakeng sa selemo sa 2018. mosebetsi wa rona, re le maaforika borwa, ke ho mamarela motsotso ona wa tshepo le ntjhafalo, esita le ho sebetsa mmoho ho netefatsa hore o etsa phapang e bonahalang maphelong a batho ba habo rona.

eng: this year, we will be initiating measures to set the country on a new path of growth, employment and transformation.
sot: monongwaha, re tla be re thakgola dikgato tsa ho beha naha tseleng e ntjha ya kgolo, mesebetsi le diphetoho.

eng: we will do this by getting social partners in our country to collaborate in building a social compact on which we will create drivers of economic recovery.
sot: re tla etsa sena ka ho mema balekane ba rona ba kahisano ka hara naha ho kena kgabong le rona mabapi le ho aha kahisano e momahaneng eo ho yona re tla utolla basusumetsi ba tsosoloso ya moruo.

eng: we have to build further on the collaboration with business and labour to restore confidence and prevent an investment downgrade once more.
sot: re lokela ho aha ho ya pele momahano hammoho le bahwebi le bosebetsi ho kgutlisa boitshepo esita le ho thibela ho theolwa ha maemo a botsetedi hape.

eng: tough decisions have to be made to close our fiscal gap, stabilise our debt and restore our state-owned enterprises to health.
sot: diqeto tse boima di tshwanela ho nkuwa bakeng sa ho kwala dikgeo ditjheleteng tsa mmuso, re tsitsise mekitlane ya rona re be re kgutlise maemo a matle a dikgwebo tsa mmuso.

eng: at the centre of our national agenda in 2018 is the creation of jobs, especially for the youth.
sot: setsiketsing sa lethathama la lenaneo la rona la naha ka 2018, ke ho thea mesebetsi, haholoholo bakeng sa batjha.

eng: we are going to embark on a number of measures to address the unemployment challenge.
sot: re tlilo sebetsana le dikgato tse mengata tsa ho rarolla phephetso ya leqeme la mesebetsi.

eng: one of the initiatives will be to convene a jobs summit within the next few months to align the efforts of every sector and every stakeholder behind the imperative of job creation.
sot: e nngwe ya dikgato tsena e tla ba ho epa seboka sa mesebetsi dikgweding tse mmalwa tse tlang, ho nyalanya bohlokwa ba tlhahiso ya mesebetsi le matsapa a lekala le leng le le leng esita le e mong le e mong ya amehang.

eng: the summit will look at what we need to do to ensure our economy grows and becomes more productive, that companies invest on a far greater scale, that workers are better equipped, and that our economic infrastructure is also expanded.
sot: seboka se tla tsepamiso maikutlo ho seo re tshwanelang ho se etsa ho netefatsa hore moruo wa rona o a hola ebile o ba le dihlahiswa tse tomanyana, hore dikhamphane di tsetela haholwanyane, hore basebetsi ba matlafatswa haholwanyane, le hore meralo ya rona ya motheo ya moruo le yona e a atollwa.

eng: we will expect this summit to come up with practical solutions and initiatives that will be implemented immediately.
sot: re tla lebella hore seboka sena se tle le ditharollole dikgato tse tshwarehang tse tla kenngwa tshebetsong hanghang.

eng: we will make a major push this year to encourage significant new investment in our economy.
sot: re tla sututsa ka matla monogwaha ho kgothaletsa matsete a matjha a bohlokwa moruong wa rona.

eng: to this end, we will organise an investment conference in the next three months, targeting both domestic and international investors, to market the compelling investment opportunities to be found in our country and there are many such opportunities.
sot: ho fihlela sena, re tla epa pitso ya botsetedi dikgweding tse tharo tse tlang, re tsepamisitse maikutlo ho batsetedi ba lapeng le ba matjhaba, ho bapatsa menyetla e hohelang e teng e tla fumaneha naheng ya rona, mme menyetla e jwalo e teng ka bongata.

eng: we are going to address the decline over many years of our manufacturing capacity, which has deeply affected employment and exports.
sot: re tlo rarolla ho nyotobela ha dilemo tse ngata ha bokgoni ba rona ba tlhahiso, bo thefutseng mesebetsi le diyantle.

eng: we will seek to reindustrialise on a scale and at a pace that draws millions of job seekers into the economy.
sot: re batla ho tsosolosa diindaseteri ka sekgahla le lebelo le tla hohela dimilione tsa ba tsomang mesebetsi hore ba kene moruong.

eng: we are going to promote greater investment in key manufacturing sectors through the strategic use of incentives and the number of other measures that government has at its disposal.
sot: re tla bapatsa matsete a maholo makaleng a ka sehloohong a tlhahiso, ka tshebediso ya mawa a ditsiane le mekgwa e meng e mengatanyana eo mmuso o nang le yona.

eng: to further stimulate manufacturing, we will forge ahead with the localisation programme, through which products like textile, clothing, furniture, rail rolling stock and water meters are designated for local procurement.
sot: ho hotetsa tlhase ya tlhahiso ho ya pele, re tla hahamalla pele ka lenaneo la tshebediso ya dihlahiswa tsa kwano lapeng, leo ka lona dihlahiswa tse kang masela, diaparo, fenetjhara, thepa ya diterene le dimitara tsa metsi di reretsweng ho rekwa kwano lapeng.

eng: we have already spent more than r57 billion on locally produced goods that may have been imported from other countries.
sot: re se re sebedisitse tjhelete e kahodimo ho r57 bilione thepeng e hlahisitsweng kwano lapeng tse ka beng di rekilwe dinaheng tse ding.

eng: that is job creation through imports and exports.
sot: seo ke tlhahiso ya mesebetsi ka ditlalapeng le diyantle.

eng: special economic zones remain important instruments we will use to attract strategic foreign and domestic direct investment, and build targeted industrial capabilities and establish new industrial hubs throughout our country.
sot: mabatowa a ikgethang a moruo a dula e le disebediswa tsa bohlokwa tseo re tla di sebedisa ho hohela matsete a mawa a dinaheng tsa kantle le a kwano lapeng ka kotloloho, le ho aha bokgoni ba diindaseteri tse hlwailweng esita le ho thea ditsha tse ntjha tsa diindaseteri ho phatlalla le naha ya rona.

eng: the process of industrialisation must be underpinned by transformation.
sot: motjha wa kaho ya diindaseteri o lokela ho matlafatswa ka diphetoho.

eng: through measures like preferential procurement and the black industrialists programme, we are developing a new generation of black men and women producers that are able to build enterprises of significant scale and capability.
sot: ka mekgwa e kang ya lenaneo la tshekamelo ya ho reka thepa ya kwano lapeng le la boraindaseteri ba batsho, re ntshetsapele moloko o motjha wa bahlahisi ba banna le basadi ba batho ba batsho ba kgonang ho aha dikgwebo tsa boemo le bokgoni ba bohlokwa.

eng: we will improve our capacity to support black professionals, deal decisively with companies that resist transformation, use competition policy to open markets up to new black entrants, and invest in the development of businesses in townships and rural areas.
sot: re tla ntlafatsa bokgoni ba rona ba ho tshehetsa diporofeshenale tsa batho ba batsho, ho sebetsana ka matla le dikhamphani tse hanang diphetoho, re sebedise leano la qothisano ya lehlokwa ho bulela batho ba batsho ba qalang ho kena mebarakeng, esita le ho tsetela ntshetsopeleng ya dikgwebo tsa makeisheneng le tsa dibaka tsa mahaeng.

eng: radical economic transformation requires that we fundamentally improve the position of black women and communities in the economy, ensuring that they are owners, managers, producers and in the end, some of them could even become financiers.
sot: phetoho e potlakileng ya moruo e hloka hore re ntlafatse ka botebo maemo a basadi ba batho ba batsho le setjhaba sa rantsho moruong, ho netefatswe hore ke beng ba thepa, batsamaisi, bahlahisi mme qetellong, ba bang ba bona ba ka qetella e le batsetedi.

eng: our most grave and most pressing challenge is youth unemployment.
sot: phephetso ya rona e bohloko ebile e tetebetsa ka ho fetisisa ke leqeme la mesebetsi batjheng.

eng: it is therefore a matter of great urgency that we draw young people in far greater numbers into productive economic activity of our country.
sot: kahoo ke taba e potlakileng ya hore re hohele batjha ka bongata ba bona, hore ba kene diketsahalong tsa moruo wa tlhahiso naheng ya rona.

eng: young south africans will be moved to the centre of our economic agenda.
sot: batjha ba maaforika borwa ba tla bewa setsiketsing sa lethathama la lenane la moruo wa rona.

eng: they are already forming a greater proportion of the labour force on our infrastructure projects and are the primary beneficiaries of programmes such as the installation of solar water heaters and the war on leaks.
sot: e se ntse e le bona ba bopang karolo e kgolo ya basebetsi diporojekeng tsa rona tsa meralo ya motheo, ebile ke bona ba mantlha ba folang melemo mananeong a kang a ho kenngwa ha difuthumetsi tsa metsi tse sebetsang ka matla a letsatsi esita le a ho lwantsha metsi a dutlang.

eng: we are taking steps in involving our youth in tackling these challenges.
sot: re boetse re nka dikgato ho kenyeletsweng ha batjha ba rona twantshong ya diphephetso tsena .

eng: we continue to draw young people in far greater numbers into productive economic activity through programmes such as the employment tax incentive.
sot: re tswela pele ho hohela batjha ka bongata ba bona, hore ba kene diketsahalong tsa moruo wa tlhahiso ka mananeo a kang ditsiane tsa lekgetho la kgiro.

eng: working in partnership with business, organised labour and community representatives, we are creating opportunities for young people to be exposed to the world of work through internships, apprenticeships, mentorship and entrepreneurship.
sot: ha re sebetsa ka selekane le baemedi ba dikgwebo, ba mekgatlo ya basebetsi le ba setjhaba, re hlahisa menyetla bakeng sa batjha hore ba rue tsebo mapatlelong a mesebetsi ka boithuto ba mesebetsi, dithupello mesebetsing, botataisuwa le bohwebi.

eng: next month, we will launch the youth employment service initiative, which will place unemployed youth in paid internships in companies across the economy.
sot: kgweding e tlang, re tla thakgola kgato ya tshebeletso ya kgiro ya batjha, e tla kenya batjha ba sa sebetseng boithutong ba mesebetsi bo lefang dikhamphaneng ho phatlalla le moruo.

eng: together with our partners in business, we have agreed to create a million such internships in the next three years.
sot: re le mmoho le balekane ba rona kgwebong, re dumellane ka ho hlahisa menyetla e jwalo ya boithuto ba mesebetsi e milione dilemong tse tharo tse tlang.

eng: if we are to respond effectively to the needs of youth, it is essential that young people articulate their views and are able to engage with government at the highest level.
sot: haeba re batla ho arabela ka bokgabane ditlhokong tsa batjha, ho bohlokwa hore batjha ba hlahise maikutlo a bona ba be ba kgone ho buisana le mmuso boemong bo hodimodimo.

eng: to this end, i will therefore be establishing a youth working group that is representative of all young south africans to ensure that our policies and programmes advance their interests.
sot: ho fihlella sena, ke tla thea setlamo sa tshebetso sa batjha se emetseng batjha bohle ba maaforika borwa ho netefatsa hore maano le mananeo a rona a ntshetsapele ditabatabelo tsa bona.

eng: infrastructure investment is key to our efforts to grow the economy, create jobs, empower small businesses and provide services to our people.
sot: botsetedi ba meralo ya motheo bo bohlokwa matsapeng a rona a ho hodisa moruo, ho hlahisa mesebetsi, ho matlafatsa dikgwebo tse nyenyane le ho fana ka ditshebeletso bathong ba habo rona.

eng: we have invested heavily in new roads, power stations, schools and other infrastructure.
sot: re tsetetse haholo mebileng e metjha, diteisheneng tsa motlakase, dikolong le meralong e meng ya motheo.

eng: as some of our projects are taking time to get off the ground and to enhance our efforts, i will assemble a team to speed up implementation of new projects, particularly water projects, health facilities and road maintenance.
sot: erekaha diporojeke tse ding tsa rona di nka nako ho thakgoha le ho matlafatsa matsapa a rona, ke tla kgobokanya sehlopha se tla akofisa ho kenngwa tshebetsong ha diporojeke tse ntjha, haholoholo diprojeke tsa metsi, dibaka tsa kalafo le tokiso ya mebila.

eng: the team will be set up and will be doing most of the work.
