eng: infrastructure is central to our economic reconstruction and recovery.
sot: meralo ya motheo ke ya bohlokwa kahong botjha le tsoseletsong ya moruo.

eng: through innovative funding and improved technical capabilities, we have prioritised infrastructure projects to support economic growth and better livelihoods, especially in energy, roads and water management.
sot: ntlafatso ya meralo ya motheo, ke yona eo re e behileng pele ka mokgwa wa tshehetso ya ditjhelete le ditshebeletso tsa setekginiki, e le ho tshehetsa kgolo ya moruo, ho ntlafatsa dibaka tseo batho ba phelang ho tsona, haholoholo ka motlakase, ditsela le phepelo ya metsi.

eng: the infrastructure fund is at the centre of this effort, with a r100 billion allocation from the fiscus over 10 years.
sot: ho beheletswe ka thoko dibilione tse 100 tsa diranta bakeng sa mosebetsi ona dilemong tse leshome.

eng: the fund is now working with state entities to prepare a pipeline of projects with an investment value of approximately r96 billion in student accommodation, social housing, telecommunications, water and sanitation and transport.
sot: mafapha a mangata a mmuso a sebedisa letlole lena diprojekeng tse bitsang dibilione tse r96 tse kenyeletsang kaho ya matlo a baithuti, matlo a setjhaba, ntlafatso ya tsa kgokahano, tsa dikgwerekgwere le metsi le tsa transporoto.

eng: several catalytic projects to the value of r21 billion are expected to start construction this year.
sot: ho lebeletswe hore diprojeke tse ka bitsang dibilione tse 21 tsa diranta di qale hona selemong sena.

eng: of this, r2.6 billion is contributed by government and the balance from the private sector and developmental finance institutions.
sot: tjheleteng ena, dibilione tse 2.6 tsa diranta di tswa ho mmuso, mme e nngwe tjhelete yona e tswa lekaleng le ikemetseng le ditshebeletsong tsa tshehetso ya ditjhelete.

eng: government will make an initial investment of r1.8 billion in bulk infrastructure, which will unlock seven private sector projects to the value of r133 billion.
sot: mmuso o tla qala ka ho kenya tjhelete e kalo ka dibilione tse 1.8 tsa diranta ntlafatsong ya meralo ya motheo, e leng se tla neha dikgwebo tse ikemetseng monyetla wa ho kena ho tse ding diprojeke tse ka bitsang dibilione tse 133 tsa diranta.

eng: for millions of south africans in rural areas, roads and bridges provide access to markets, employment opportunities and social services.
sot: ho dimilione tsa batho ba mahaeng, mmila le marokgo ke tsa bohlokwa ho bona hore ba finyelle mesebetsing, mabenkeleng le ditshebeletsong tsa setjhaba.

eng: yet, many children still have to brave overflowing rivers to reach schools and motorists have to battle impassable roads to reach the next town.
sot: ho ntse ho na le bana ba bangata ba tshelang dinoka tse tletseng ho ya dikolong le boradikoloi ba sokolang ho ya ditoropong ka lebaka la bobe ba ditsela.

eng: we are therefore upscaling the welisizwe rural bridges programme to deliver 95 bridges a year from the current 14. our south african national defence force (sandf) is the implementing agent of the welisizwe programme, and has demonstrated the expertise of sandf engineers in bridge construction.
sot: re nyolla sekgahla sa tshebetso lenaneong la welisizwe la kaho ya marokgo dibakeng tsa mahaeng ka ho aha marokgo a 95 ka selemo ha ho bapiswa le a 14 a ha jwale.

eng: earlier this week, i was in thakgalane village limpopo to launch a new road that is going to make a huge difference in the lives of neighbouring communities.
sot: sesole sa rona sa naha, ke sona se tsamaisang leano lena la welisizwe mme se bontshitse boiphihlelo kahong ya ena ya marokgo.

eng: this road was constructed using block paving and other materials, which is a method that enables us to build durable roads faster and more cost-effectively.
sot: botjheng ba beke ena, ke ne ke le motsaneng wa thakgalane mane limpopo ho ya thakgola kaho ya mmila o motjha o tla thusa ho hokahanya metsana e mmedi sebakeng seo.

eng: this social enterprise programme includes access roads in limpopo and eastern cape, gravel to surface upgrades in the free state and north west, and capacity and connectivity improvements in the western cape.
sot: mmila ya mofuta ona e ahwa ho sebediswa ditene tsena tsa ho lokisa mabala malapeng, mme ona ke mokgwa o sa bitsing.

eng: the project is made of the ntabelanga dam and lalini dam, irrigation infrastructure and hydo-electric plant, ntabelanga water treatment works and bulk distribution infrastructure to reticulate to the neighboring communities.
sot: mosebetsi ona, o kenyeletsa ho aha mebila e kenellang metsaneng ya limpopo le kapa botjhabela, mme foreisitata le leboya bophirima teng ba tla fetola mmila ya lepoto ho e etsa ya sekontiri.

eng: the closing date for the first of the two-stage procurement process is scheduled to close later this month, with the preferred bidder likely to be announced in september 2022. government is introducing an innovative social infrastructure delivery mechanism to address issues that afflict the delivery of school infrastructure.
sot: kapa bophirima teng ba tla ntlafatsa mmila e hokelang metsana ya teng.

eng: the mechanism will address the speed, financing and funding, quality of delivery, mass employment and maintenance.
sot: mmuso o thakgotse lenaneo la phepelo ya metsi la umzimvubu.

eng: the new delivery mechanism will introduce a special purpose vehicle, working with prominent development finance institutions and the private sector, to deliver school education infrastructure.
sot: projeke ena e kenyeletsa letamo la ntabelanga le la lalini, sitsi sa metjhini ya ho tshella le ho pompa metsi, le sa ho a hlwekisa sa hona ntabelanga, mmoho le phepelo ya ona metsaneng e haufi.

eng: this approach is being piloted in schools in the northern cape and eastern cape.
sot: letsatsi la ho kwala bakeng sa ho kenya dikopo tsa ho etsa mosebetsi ona, ke mafelo a kgwedi ena, ba tla atleha mona, ba tla phatlalatswa ka loetse 2022. mmuso o tla le mahlale a tharollo mathateng a meralo ya motheo dikolong.

eng: this includes the development of a hydrogen society roadmap for the next 10 years as well as a green hydrogen strategy for the northern cape, supporting the development of a green hydrogen pipeline worth around r270 billion.
sot: sena se latela katleho eo mmuso o e fihletseng nakong ya selemo se fetileng lenaneong la hydrogen sa, moo afrika borwa e ileng ya tswa pele mmarakeng ona o motjha wa kgwebo.

eng: the damage caused by the theft of scrap metal and cable on our infrastructure like electricity, trains and other vital services is enormous.
sot: lenaneo leo, le kenyeletsa meralo ya dilemo tse leshome ya lenaneo lena la hydrogen society bakeng sa kapa leboya, e leng tshehetso ya tlhahiso ya motlakase wa metsi o bitsang dibilione tse 270 tsa diranta.

eng: we will take decisive steps this year both through improved law enforcement and by considering further measures to address the sale or export of such scrap metal.
sot: tshenyo e bakwang ke boshodu ba dithapo tsa motlakase le ditshepe, e thefula meralo ya motheo e kang diterene le phepelo ya motlakase.

eng: an important pillar of our errp is to revitalise our manufacturing base and create globally competitive export industries.
sot: re tlo nka mehato le mekgatlo e qobellang melao re tiise letsoho tabeng ya theko le thekiso ya dintho tsena.

eng: in the past year, we launched new master plans in the steel industry, furniture and global business services.
sot: tshiya ya bohlokwa tsoseletsong ya moruo ke ho matlafatsa lekala la tlhahiso le ho ba le diindasteri tsa boemo ba matjhaba tse romelang thepa matjhabeng.

eng: through these plans, business, government and labour are working together to increase production and create more jobs in the sector.
sot: ka maano ana, mmuso, borakgwebo le mekgatlo ya basebetsi, ba sebetsa mmoho ho eketsa tlhahiso le menyetla ya mesebetsi makaleng ana.

eng: in the clothing industry, a number of retailers have announced ambitious localisation sourcing plans.
sot: mabenkele a mangata indastering ya diaparo a phatlaladitse taba ya hore a lohotha ho reka thepa ya ona mona lapeng.

eng: one of these retailers, foschini, kindly made the suit that i am wearing today at its new formal wear factory, prestige epping.
sot: le leng la mabenkele ao ke la foschini, leo e leng lona le rokileng sutu ena eo ke e apereng.

eng: five years ago, more than 80% of all foschini group merchandise came from the east.
sot: ba e rokile mane fektring ya bona e ntjha e bitswang, prestige epping.

eng: today, nearly half of the merchandise is locally made.
sot: dilemong tse hlano tse fetileng, persente tse ka bang 80 tsa diaparo tsa ha foschini di ne di tlhoha dinaheng tsa botjhabela.

eng: the genuine leather shoes i am wearing were made by members of the national union of leather and allied workers from bolton footwear in cape town and dick whittington shoes in pietermaritzburg.
sot: dieta tsena tseo ke di rwetseng tsona di rokilwe ka kopanelo ke ditho tsa mokgatlo wa basebetsi ba dihlahiswa tsa letlalo ho tswa bolton footwear, kapa le dick whittington shoes mane pietermaritzburg.

eng: nearly four years ago, we set ourselves a target of mobilising r1.2 trillion in new investment over five years.
sot: nakong e ka etsang dilemo tse nne tse fetileng, re ne re ipehetse ho etsa matsete a ka bang ditrilione tse 1.2 tsa diranta nakong ya dilemo tse hlano.

eng: by the time of the third south africa investment conference in november 2020, we had reached r776 billion in investment commitments.
sot: nako ya kopano ya boraro ya matsete ka pudungwana 2020, re ne re se re bokeleditse dibilione tse 776 tsa diranta bakeng sa matsete ao.

eng: next month, on the 24th of march, we will be holding the fourth south africa investment conference in johannesburg.
sot: kgweding e tlang ka la 24 tlhakubele, re tla be re tshwere kopano ya bone ya matsete mane lejweleputswa.

eng: we will showcase the many investment opportunities available as south africa continues its recovery from the covid-19 pandemic, and report back on the progress of previous commitments.
sot: ho yona re tlo lekola menyetla eo afrika borwa e bileng le yona ho tswela pele le ho ikaha botjha ka mora koduwa ya covid-19, mme re tla tlisa tlaleho ya kopano eo.

eng: following the resolutions of the african union summit over the past weekend, trading can now begin under the african continental free trade area agreementsouth african companies are poised to play a key role in taking up the opportunities that this presents for preferential access to other african markets.
sot: kopanong ya dinaha tsa afrika e fetileng, re nkile tumellano ya hore mosebetsi wa kgwebisano o ka qala ho latela leano la tumellano ya kgwebisano ntle le ditjeho dinaheng tsa afrika.

eng: the free trade agreement is about africa taking charge of its destiny and growing its economies faster.
sot: dikhamphane tsa afrika borwa di tla tlameha ho sebedisa monyetla ona ho ka etsa kgwebo dinaheng tse ding tsa afrika.

eng: we will continue to pursue africa’s health sovereignty, working with other african countries and international partners to support the strengthening of the continent’s capacity to respond to pandemics.
sot: tumellano ena ya ho hwebisana ntle le ditefello, e neha dinaha tsa afrika bokgoni ba ho itshwarela dintho tsa tsona mmoho le ho nyolla moruo ka potlako.

eng: we will increase our efforts to develop africa’s ability to manufacture vaccines.
sot: re tla tswela pele le ho ntlafatsa tsa bophelo afrika re sebetsa le dinaha tse ding tsa afrika le tsa matjhaba ho leka ho matlafatsa afrika ka mora koduwa ena.

eng: we have made significant progress here in south africa.
sot: rona jwalo ka afrika borwa, re se re hatetse pele karolong eo.

eng: we now have two south african companies – aspen and biovac – with contracts to produce covid-19 vaccines.
sot: hona jwale, re na le khamphane tse pedi tsa afrika borwa – aspen and biovac – tse hlahisang ente ya covid-19.

eng: two additional vaccine projects have also been announced.
sot: ho na le tse ding diprojeke tse pedi tse phatlaladitsweng tsa tlhahiso ya ente.

eng: in addition, we have full local production capability for ventilators, hand sanitisers, medical-grade face masks and gloves and therapeutic drugs and anaesthetics.
sot: ho feta moo, re na le khamphane tse hlahisang metjhini ya ho hema, dibolaya dikokwanahloko, dimonkwana, diatlana le meriana.

eng: this production capability worth many billions of rand of production annually, has been put in place in less than two years.
sot: tllhahiso ena e bitsang dibilione tsa tjhelete ka selemo, e thakgotswe nakong e sa feteng selemo e fetileng.

eng: south african products have been exported to other african countries, securing them vital supplies and expanding jobs for young south africans.
sot: dihlahiswa tsa mona afrika borwa di romelwa dinaheng tse ding tsa afrika, e leng se thehang menyetla ya mesebetsi bakeng sa batjha ba afrika borwa.

eng: while we help existing industries to grow, we are also nurturing new opportunities for growth and jobs.
sot: leha re thusa diindasteri tse teng ho hola, re boetse hape re hodisa le menyetla e metjha e hlahang, e ka tlisang menyetla ya mesebetsi.

eng: government and the private sector have worked closely together to grow the global business services sector from a small group of companies to one of the world’s leading players.
sot: mmuso le lekala le ikemetseng, ba sebeditse mmoho ho theha tshebeletso ya dikgwebo tsa matjhaba ka ho kopanya mmoho dikgwebo tse nyane mme ya eba khamphane ya bohlokwa maemong a matjhaba.

eng: the global business services sector is on track to create 500 000 new jobs over the next few years.
sot: mokgatlo wa matjhaba wa ditshebeletso tsa dikgwebo, o motjheng wa ho theha menyetla ya mesebetsi e metjha e 500 000 dilemong tse mmalwa tse tlang.

eng: the hemp and cannabis sector has the potential to create more than 130 000 new jobs.
sot: lekala le hwebang ka matekwana, lona le ka theha mesebetsi e ka bang 130 000. re lokisa meralo ya tshebediso ya semela sena e le hore lekala lena le tle le etse phaello e kgolo jwalo ka dinaha tse kang lesotho.

eng: we are therefore streamlining the regulatory processes so that the hemp and cannabis sector can thrive like it is in other countries such as lesotho.
sot: batho ba kapa botjhabela le kwazulu-natal, le dibakeng tse ding, ba emetse feela ha phala e lla, ba kene temeng ba hwebe ka semela sena sa kgale, ba hlahise dihlahiswa tse ntjha ho sona.

eng: our people in the eastern cape, kwazulu-natal and elsewhere are ready to farm with this age-old commodity and bring it to market in new and innovative forms.
sot: ditshebeletso tse ding tsa setjhaba tse ka thusang setjhaba sa rona ke tsa kgudiso ya bana, booki, bosebeletsi ba setjhaba le tse ding.

eng: the social economy, including early childhood development, nursing, social work and community services, has significant potential not only to create jobs, but to provide vital services that communities need.
sot: ditshebeletso tsena, di ke se thehe menyetla ya mesebetsi feela, empa di ka ba bohlokwa le setjhabeng.

eng: some of the country’s mature industries also have a lot to offer in revamping the industrial and manufacturing potential of our country.
sot: diindasteri tse ding tse seng di tswetse pele, di na le seo di ka thusang ka sona ho ntlafatseng diindasteri le tlhahiso ya naha ena.

eng: the agriculture sector has significant potential for job creation in crops such as citrus, table and dried grapes, subtropical fruit, avocadoes, berries and nuts.
sot: lekala la tsa temo le lona le na le bokgoni ba ho theha menyetla ya mosebetsi ditholwaneng tse kang tse boditsana, mangangajane a morara, monokotshwai, matokomane le ditholwana tse melang dibakeng tse futhumetseng.

eng: masterplans in the sugar and poultry industries are contributing significantly to increased investment, improved production and transformation.
sot: maano a indasteri ya tswekere le ya dikgoho, le ona a bile le seabo ho nyolleng matsete ka ntlafalo ya ona tlhahisong le diphetohong tsa ona.

eng: to attract investors into the mining minerals needed in the new global economy, we will soon be finalising our mining exploration strategy.
sot: ho ka hohela boramatsete ba matjhaba ho dirashwa tse rashwang merafong ya rona, re tla tlameha ho phethela maano a ntlafatso ya merafo ya rona.

eng: we will continue to support the development of the upstream gas industry, as it holds huge potential for job creation and broader economic development.
sot: re tla tswela pele le ho tshehetsa tlhahiso ya kgase hobane le yona e tla thusa ntlafatsong ya moruo le ho theheng menyetla ya mesebetsi.

eng: we will ensure that this is done in strict accordance with the environmental and other laws of our country, and that where there are differences, we work together to resolve them in the interest of our country and its people.
sot: re tla netefatsa hore tsena di etsahala ho ipapisitswe le melao ya tsa tikoloho le e meng ya naha ena ya rona, mme moo ho bonahalang dikarohano teng, re di lokise hantle ka moya wa kutlwisisano molemong wa naha le setjhaba sa rona.

eng: we live in one of the regions of the world that is most affected by climate change.
sot: re phela karolong ya lefatse e angwang haholo ke ho fetofetoha ha maemo a lehodimo.

eng: we frequently experience droughts, floods and other extreme weather events associated with global warming.
sot: ka lebaka lena, re ba le mathata a kang komello, dikgohola le a mang mathata ka lebaka la maemo a ho futhumala ha lehodimo.

eng: recently floods have affected a number of provinces, including kwazulu-natal, gauteng and the eastern cape.
sot: hona jwale, ho sa tswa ba le dikgohola diprofensing tse kang kwazulu-natal, gauteng le kapa botjhabela.

eng: these have already caused enormous damage to infrastructure and livelihoods.
sot: tsena kaofela di bakile tshenyo meralong ya motheo le malapeng a batho.

eng: in the last year, we have made important strides in the fight against climate change, and, at the same time, securing our economic competitiveness.
sot: selemong se fetileng, re ile ra nka mehato ya bohlokwa ho lwantshana le ho fetofetoha ha maemo a lehodimo mme le moruo le ona wa ba betere.

eng: for the first time, our climate targets are compatible with limiting warming to 1.5°c.
sot: e bile kgetlo la pele naha ya rona e kgona ho ipapisa le pehelo e behilweng ya motjheso, e leng wa 1.5°c.

eng: this is the goal that all countries agreed to as part of the paris climate agreement, and is essential to prevent the worst effects of climate change.
sot: ena ke tekanyetso eo dinaha tsohle di dumellaneng ka yona tumellanong ya maemo a lehodimo mane paris, mme yona e etseditswe ho thibela mathata a ka bakwang ke ho mpefala ha maemo a lehodimo.

eng: since i established the presidential climate commission a little more than a year ago, it has done much work to support a just transition to a sustainable, inclusive, resilient and low-carbon economy.
sot: haesale ke theha komeshene ya mopresidente ya maemo a lehodimo nakong e etsang selemo e fetileng, tema e se e bonahetse ya ho fokotsa ho silafala ha moya.

eng: at the international climate conference in glasgow last november, south africa struck a historic r131 billion deal with the european union, france, germany, united kingdom and the united states.
sot: kopanong ya matjhaba ya maemo a lehodimo ka pudungwana ngwahola, mane glasgow, afrika borwa e ile ya etsa nalane ka ho saena tumellano ya dibilione tse 131 tsa diranta le mokgatlo wa dinaha tsa yuropa, fora, jeremane, united kingdom le amerika.

eng: this first-of-its-kind partnership will involve repurposing and repowering some of the coal plants that are reaching the end of their lives, and creating new livelihoods for workers and communities most impacted by this change.
sot: tumellano ena ya mofuta wa yona, e tla kenyeletsa ho fetolwa ha ditsi tse fehlang motlakase wa mashala tse tsofetseng, hore di sebetse ka mokgwa o motjha o tla tswela basebeletsi le setjhaba molemo.

eng: to ensure that south africa is able to derive the full benefit of this and other partnerships, i have appointed mr daniel mminele, a former deputy governor of the reserve bank, as head of the presidential climate finance task team to lead the mobilisation of funds for our just transition.
sot: ho netefatsa hore re kgola molemo tumellanong ena, le tse ding, ke thontshe ntate daniel mminele, motlatsi wa mehleng wa mookamedi wa banka ya resefe ho etella pele komiti ya mopresidente e shebaneng le ditjhelete tsa ho fetofetoha ha maemo a lehodimo, e le hore diphetoho tsena di tle di etsahale ka nepo.

eng: properly managed, the energy transition will benefit all.
sot: ha dintho di etswa ka nepo, ho fetolwa hona ha ho fehlwa ha motlakase ho ka tswela motho ohle molemo.

eng: renewable energy production will make electricity cheaper and more dependable, and will allow our industries to remain globally competitive.
sot: tlhahiso ya motlakase ka mokgwa wa tlhaho ho tla theola theko ya ona, ho etse hore o tsitse, mme le diindasteri di kgone ho tshetjwa maemong a matjhaba.

eng: investments in electric vehicles and hydrogen will equip south africa to meet the global clean energy future.
sot: ha re ka qala ho sebedisa dikoloi tse tsamayang ka motlakase, le ho sebedisa motlakase o fehlwang ka metsi, re ka ba le motlakase o hlwekileng haholo.

eng: we will be able to expand our mining industry in strategic minerals that are crucial for clean energy, like platinum, vanadium, cobalt, copper, manganese and lithium.
sot: re tla etsa maano a ho atolla merafo ya rona ho rashweng ha diminerale tse bohlokwa motlakaseng o hlwekileng tse kang platinum, vanadium, cobalt, koporo, manganese le lithium.

eng: we also have a unique opportunity in green hydrogen, given our world-class solar and wind resources and local technology and expertise.
sot: re boetse hape re na le monyetla wa ho hlahisa motlakse o hlweileng o fehlwang ka letsatsi le moya re sebedisa thekenoloji le boiphihlelo ba rona.

eng: all of these measures – from structural reforms to support for smmes, investments in infrastructure and the emergence of new sectors – will drive a turnaround in economic growth driven by the private sector growth over the coming years.
sot: mehatong ena kaofela – ho tloha dintlafatsong meralong ya motheo, ho ya tshehetsong ya dikgwebo, ho etsa matsete meralo ya metheo, le ho theheng makala a matjha – tsena kaofela di tla thusa lekala le ikemetseng ho nyolla moruo wa rona dilemong tsena tse tlang.

eng: we know, however, that even with the best business environment and much faster rates of economic growth, it will take time for the private sector to create enough jobs for the millions of south africans who need them.
sot: leha ho le jwalo, re a tseba hore leha maemo a dikgwebo a ka ba matle ho le ho kae, ho ntse ho tla nka nako e telele hore dikgwebo di kgone ho theha menyetla ya mesebetsi e ka lekanang dimilione tsa maafrika borwa ana a sa sebetseng.

eng: our intent is to leave no one behind.
sot: ha re a ikemisetsa hore ho be teng ya tla salla morao.

eng: that is why we are expanding public and social employment.
sot: ke ka hona re eketsang ka taba ya ho hirwa ke mmuso le ke mekgatlo ya setjhaba.

eng: the first two phases of the presidential employment stimulus programmes, which we launched in october 2020 have supported over 850 000 opportunities.
sot: mekgahlelo e mmedi ya leano le mopresidente la theho ya mesebetsi, e ileng ya thakgolwa ka mphalane 2020, e ile ya thusa batho ba fetang 850 000. persente tse fetang tse 80 bathong bana, e ne e le batjha, ha ba fetang tse 60 bona e le basadi.

eng: it has supported young women like tracy nkosi from springs, who was employed as an education assistant at welgedag primary school, and who says this opportunity has motivated her to further her studies in the educational sphere.
sot: ho thusahetse batho ba kang tracy nkosi wa springs, ya neng a hirelwe ho thusa ho ruta sekolong sa poraimari sa welgedag, mme o re monyetla ona o mo kgothaditse hore a ntshetse dithuto tsa hae pele lekaleng lena la tsa thuto.

eng: it has also supported mama nosipho cekwana from impendle in kwazulu-natal who used her farming input voucher to buy maize, manure and supplements for her livestock.
sot: ho boetse ha thusahala le mme nosipho cekwana wa impendle, kwazulu-natal, ya neng a sebedisetse vaotjhara ya hae ya tsa temo ho rekeng poone, manyolo le meriana ya diphoofolo tsa hae.

eng: the total number of direct beneficiaries will soon rise to over one million south africans.
sot: maafrika borwa a seng a unne molemo leanong lena a se a tla fihla ho milione.

eng: this includes over half a million young people appointed as education assistants, making it the largest youth employment programme ever undertaken in our history.
sot: mona re kenyeletsa le batjha ba fetang halofo ya milione, ba ileng ba hirwa ho ba bathusi ba matitjhere, mme lena e bile leano le leholo ka ho fetisisa la ho hira batjha.

eng: the employment stimulus will also enable the department of home affairs to recruit 10 000 unemployed young people for the digitisation of paper records, enhancing their skills and contributing to the modernisation of citizen services.
sot: leano lena, le tla boela le kenella le lefapheng la ditaba tsa lehae, moo ho tlang ho hirwa teng batjha ba 10 0000 ba sa sebetseng ho kenya dikhomputareng dintlha tsa lefapha lena tse ngotsweng fatshe.

eng: the social employment fund will create a further 50 000 work opportunities using the capability of organisations beyond government, in areas such as urban agriculture, early childhood development, public art and tackling gender-based violence.
sot: letlole la theho ya mesebetsi la ditshebeletso tsa setjhaba, le lona le tla theha e meng mesebetsi e 50,000, le sebedisa ditshebeletso tsa mekgatlo eo e seng ya mmuso, makaleng a kang tsa temo dibakeng tsa ditoropong, kgudiso ya bana, tsa bonono mmoho le twantsho ya tlhekefetso ya bonng.

eng: in addition to expanding public employment, we are providing support to young people to prepare them for work and link them to opportunities.
sot: ntle le moo, re boetse re fa batjha tsebo le maele bakeng sa kgiro le ho ba fumanela le menyetla e teng.

eng: to encourage hiring by smaller businesses, we will be increasing the value and expanding the criteria for participation in the employment tax incentive.
sot: re tlameha ho kgothaletsa dikgwebo tse nyane ho hira batho ka hore re eketse melemo ya seo ha re tla tabeng ya lekgetho la kgiro.

eng: for several years, this has been an effective way to encourage companies to hire new work seekers.
sot: ena haesale e le tsela e sebetsang ya ho kgothaletsa dikhamphane ho hira batho ba batjha.

eng: the changes to the incentive will make it easier for small businesses in particular to hire young people.
sot: ha ho se ho na le melemonyana e itseng, teng ho tla ba bobebe hore dikgwebo tse nyane di hire batjha.

eng: the minister of finance will announce the details of these changes in the budget.
sot: letona la matlotlo le tla fana ka dintlha tsa diphetoho tsena ha le se le tshetleha puo ya lona ya kabo ya matlotlo.

eng: we call on companies to support this effort, take up the incentive and give young people a place in the world of work.
sot: re etsa kgoeletso ho dikhamphane ho tshehetsa leano lena, di hire batjha.

eng: mobi platform for young work seekers to access opportunities and support now has more than 2.3 million young south africans registered.
sot: e se e le batjha ba fetang dimilione tse 2.3 ba seng ba ingodisitse ho websaete ya batjha ba batlang mosebetsi e leng ya sayouth.

eng: of these over 600 000 have been placed into employment opportunities.
sot: palong e ka hodimo, ba 600 000 ba se ba fumane dikgeo tsa mesebetsi.

eng: a revitalised national youth service will recruit its first cohort of 50 000 young people during the next year, creating opportunities for young people to contribute to their communities, develop their skills and grow their employability.
sot: leano le ntlafaditsweng la naha la ditshebeletso tsa batjha, le tla hira sehlopha sa pele sa batjha ba 50 000 nakong ya selemo e tlang.

eng: the department of higher education and training will place 10,000 unemployed tvet graduates in workplaces from april 2022. in preparing this sona, i was assisted by two young south africans who are working as interns in the presidency, ms naledi malatji and ms kearabetswe mabatle.
sot: lefapha la thuto e phahameng le tla hira batjha ba tswang dikoletjheng tsa tvet ba 10,000 ba sa sebetseng ho tloha ka kgwedi ya mmesa 2022. ha ke ne ke lokisa sona ena, ke ne ke thuswa ka batjha ba babedi ba afrika borwa ba ithutang mosebetsi kantorong ya mopresidente, bona ke naledi malatji le kearabetswe mabatle.

eng: they told me about the pain felt by young people who find themselves with a qualification, but are unemployed because of lack of experience.
sot: ba mpolelletse ka bohloko ba batjha ba nang le mangolo a thuto empa ba sa fumane mosebetsi hobane ba se na boiphihlelo.

eng: this forces many into jobs that have little or nothing to do with what they studied.
sot: sena se etsa ba qetelle ba etsa mesebetsi eo ba neng ba sa ithutela yona.

eng: all of the measures i have outlined are essential to provide young people with the work experience that they need to take their first step into the labour market.
sot: maano ao ke seng ke buile ka ona kaofela, re a etsetsa hore batjha ba rona ba fumane boiphihlelo bona bo hlokahalang hore motho a hirwe.

eng: we are calling on the private sector to support these measures – and, wherever possible, to drop experience as a hiring requirement – to give as many young people as possible their first job.
sot: re etsa kgoeletso ho lekala le ikemetseng hore le tshehetse leano lena – mme moo ho kgonehang, boiphihlelo ha bo a tlameha ho ba se hlokahalang ha o batla mosebetsi – e leng ho leka ho thusa batjha ba bangata hore ba kgone ho qala ho fumana mesebetsi.

eng: as we work to grow the economy and create jobs, we will expand support to poor families to ensure that no person in this country has to endure the pain and indignity of hunger.
sot: jwalo ka ha re sebeletsa ho nyolla moruo, le ho theha menyetla ya mesebetsi, re tla eketsa tshehetso malapeng a fumanehileng, ho netefatsa hore ha ho motho ya robalang ka lephako naheng ena.

eng: our social protection system is among the greatest achievements of the democratic government, reaching more than 18 million people every month.
sot: ditjhelete tsa dithuso tsa mmuso, ke e nngwe ya katleho tsa mmuso wa rona wa demokrasi, mme di thusa batho ba fetang dimilione tse 18 ka kgwedi.

eng: without this support, millions more people would live in dire poverty.
sot: ntle le thuso ena, dimilione tsa batho di ne di tla bolawa ke tlala.

eng: since the onset of covid-19, the social relief of distress grant has provided support to more than 10 million unemployed people who were most vulnerable to the impact of the pandemic.
sot: haesale ho qala covid-19, ho bile le tshehetso ya tjhelete ya kimollo ho batho ba fetang dimilione tse 10 ba sa sebetseng, ba neng ba se na letho ka lebaka la koduwa ena.

eng: some people used that money to start businesses.
sot: ba bang ba batho bana ba qadile dikgwebo ka tjhelete ena.

eng: mr thando makhubu from soweto received the r350 grant for seven months last year, and saved it to open an ice-cream store that now employs four people.
sot: ntate thando makhubu wa soweto o ne a fumane tjhelete ya r350 ngwahola dikgwedi tse supileng.

eng: mr lindokuhle msomi, an unemployed tv producer from kwamashu hostel, saved the r350 grant he received for nine months to start a fast food stall and to support his family.
sot: o ile a boloka tjhelete ena dikgwedi tseo kaofela mme o qadile kgwebo ya ice-cream eo a hirileng batho ba bane ho yona.

eng: as much as it has had a substantial impact, we must recognise that we face extreme fiscal constraints.
sot: leha tjhelete ena e thusa, empa re tlameha ho tseba hore mmuso le ona ha o na tjhelete hantle.

eng: a fiscal crisis would hurt the poor worst of all through the deterioration of the basic services on which they rely.
sot: ho se be le tjhelete ha mmuso, ho ama mafutsana haholo hobane ho thefula ditshebeletso tsa mmuso tseo a tshepetseng ho tsona haholo.

eng: mindful of the proven benefits of the grant, we will extend the r350 grant for one further year, to the end of march 2023. during this time, we will engage in broad consultations and detailed technical work to identify the best options to replace this grant.
sot: jwalo ka ha re bone molemo wa tjhelete ena ya r350 setjhabeng, re tla eketsa nako ya yona ho fihlela ka tlhakubele 2023. nakong eo, re tla be ntse re etsa dipuisano re sheba hore ke ofe mokgwa oo re ka o sebedisang wa thuso ya tjhelete bakeng sa yona ha e se e fela.

eng: any future support must pass the test of affordability, and must not come at the expense of basic services or at the risk of unsustainable spending.
sot: pele re ka qala ho fana ka tjhelete eo, re tla tlameha ho bona hore mmuso o tla kgona ho tswela pele le yona na, le hore ha e no thefula tjhelete ya ditshebeletso tsa setjhaba kapa ho sheba hore mmuso o tla kgona ho e lefa nako e telele.

eng: it remains our ambition to establish a minimum level of support for those in greatest need.
sot: ke maikemisetso a rona ho ba le tekanyetso ya tshehetso ho ba hlokang.

eng: expanding access to land is vital for our efforts to reduce hunger and provide people with meaningful livelihoods.
sot: ho thusa hore batho ba be le lefatshe la bona, ho tla thusa ho fokotsa tlala, le ho etsa hore batho ba phele maphelo a betere.

eng: we are moving ahead with land reform in terms of the constitution, and anticipate the approval of the expropriation bill during this year.
sot: ntse re tswela pele le ho buseletsa batho lefatshe ho latela molaotheo wa rona, mme selemong sena, re tlo pasisa molao o dumellang ho nkuwa ha lefatshe ho bao e seng la bona.

eng: the establishment of the agriculture and land reform development agency will be finalised this year.
sot: ho thehwa ha akgente ya tsa temo le ntlafatsa ya ho kgutliswa ha lefatshe, ho tla phethelwa selemong sena.

eng: the department of public works and infrastructure will finalise the transfer of 14 000 hectares of state land to the housing development agency.
sot: lefapha la mesebetsi ya setjhaba le meralo ya motheo, le phethela ho fetisetswa ha lefatshe leo e ka bang dihektara tse 14 000 la mmuso ho akgente e ahang matlo.

eng: we have enough arable land to support millions of thriving small-scale farmers in poultry, livestock, fruit and vegetables.
sot: re na le lefatshe le lekaneng le ka sebedisetswang temo, le ka sebediswa ke dimilione tsa borapolasi ba dikgoho, diphoofolo, meroho le ditholwana.

eng: through the presidential employment stimulus and the solidarity fund, over 100 000 farmers have already received input vouchers to expand their production.
sot: ka leano la mopresidente la kgiro le letlole la kopanelo, borapolasi ba bangata ba se ba fumane divaotjhara ho atolla tlhahiso tsa bona.

eng: this scheme has proven to be effective and impactful.
sot: leano lena, le bontshitse le sebetsa le bile le le molemo.

eng: the agriculture sector has also recognised the importance of supporting small-scale farmers and integrating them into value chains.
sot: lekala la tsa temo, le ile la elellwa bohlokwa ba ho tshehetsa borapolasi ba sa leng banyane mme ba ba kenya lenaneo la bareki ba bona.

eng: through the sugar master plan, the industry has provided r225 million to over 12 000 small-scale sugar cane growers as part of a r1 billion commitment to support black farmers.
sot: leano la ntlafatso ya indasteri ya tswekere, le se le fane ka tjhelete e ballwang ho dimilione tse r225 ho borapolasi ba fetang 12 000 ba banyane ba lemang mmoba, mme bona ke bopaki ba boinehelo ba mmuso ba ho tshehetsa borapolasi ba batsho.

eng: we will be expanding the provision of input vouchers and calling on other sectors to join this effort, so that we can collectively reach up to 250 000 small-scale farmers this year.
sot: re tla eketsa divaotjhara tsena mme re etsa kgoeletso ho makala a mang hore le ona a kenye letsoho e le hore re tle re kgone ho finyella ho borapolasi ba 250 000 selemong sena.

eng: none of our efforts to revive our economy will succeed if we do not tackle the scourge of corruption once and for all.
sot: matsapa a rona a ho tsoseletsa moruo a ke ke a atleha haeba re sa lwantshe taba ya bobodu.

eng: since the beginning of the year, i have been provided with the first two parts of the report of the commission of inquiry into state capture headed by acting chief justice raymond zondo.
sot: mathwasong a selemo sena, ke se ke fumane karolo tse pedi tsa pele tsa tlaleho ya komeshene ya dipatlisiso ka menyenyetsi ya kgapo ya puso e neng e eteletswe pele ke moahlodi e moholo wa naha ya tshwereng mokobobo, raymond zondo.

eng: while the definitive conclusion has yet to be delivered at the end of this month, the first two parts of the report make it plain that there was indeed ‘state capture’.
sot: leha tlaleho ya teng e so felle, empa karolo tsena tse pedi di beha dintho pepeneneng hore ‘kgapo ya puso’ yona e etsahetse.

eng: this means that public institutions and state-owned enterprises (soes) were infiltrated by a criminal network intent on looting public money for private gain.
sot: sena se bolela hore dikhamphane tsa mmuso di ne di kenelletswe ke mashodu a neng a ikemiseditse ho nka tjhelete ya mmuso a ithuise ka yona.

eng: the reports have detailed the devastating effects of this criminal activity on south african airways, transnet, denel, south african revenue service (sars) and government communications.
sot: tlaleho ena, e hlalosa ka ho otloloha ka moo diketso tsa bobodu di neng di etsahala ka teng khamphaneng ya bofofise ya afrika borwa, ho transnet, denel, kantorong ya afrika borwa ya pokello ya lekgetho (sars) mmoho le lefapheng la mmuso la diphatlalaso.

eng: state capture had a direct and very concrete negative impact on the lives of all south africans, but especially the poorest and most vulnerable members of our society.
sot: kgapo ena ya puso e bile le kgahlamelo e mpe maphelong a maafrika borwa, empa haholoholo ho ba futsanehileng le ba hlophehileng.

eng: it has weakened the ability of the state to deliver services and to meet the expectations and constitutional rights of people.
sot: e entse hore mmuso o se kgone ho tlisa ditshebeletso bathong, le ho fihlela se hlokwang ke molaotheo mabapi le ditokelo tsa batho.

eng: we must now do everything in our power to ensure that it never happens again.
sot: jwale re tlameha ho netefatsa hore taba ena ha e boele e etsahala hape.

eng: my responsibility is to ensure that the commission report is properly and carefully considered and then acted upon.
sot: boikarabelo ba ka ke hore re latela se tlalehong, mme re nke mehato e tshwanelang.

eng: by no later than 30 june, i will present a plan of action in response to the commission’s recommendations.
sot: pele ho la 30 phpjane, ke tla bolela mehato eo ke tla e nka ho latela dikgothaletso tsa komeshene.

eng: we will, as the commission’s first report recommends, strengthen the system to protect whistle-blowers, who are a vital safeguard in the fight against corruption and who take huge personal risk in reporting wrongdoing.
sot: jwalo ka ha komeshene e kgothaletsa, re tla tiisa tsela ya ho sireletsa ba pepesang bobodu, e leng bona batho ba bohlokwa twantshong ena ya bobodu, ka ho beha maphelo a bona kotsing ka ho pepesa ketso tsena.

eng: we are doing a detailed review of all applicable legislation and a comparative study of other jurisdictions to strengthen whistle-blower protection.
sot: re ntse re lokola melao botjha ho sheba hore na re ka tiisa tshireletso ya bona jwang.

eng: the relevant law enforcement agencies are taking the necessary steps to address the immediate concern about the safety of whistle blowers.
sot: makala a tshireletso a ikarabellang, a sheba mekgwa e potlakang e ka sebediswang ho sireletsa batho bana.

eng: many individuals and companies that the commission has found were responsible for state capture must now be held to account.
sot: batho le dikhamphane tse ikarabellang bobodung bona ba kgapo ya puso, ba tlameha ho fumana kotlo e ba tshwanelang.

eng: i have every confidence that the national prosecuting authority (npa) will carry out the further investigations that the commission has recommended, and that it will bring the members of the criminal network that infiltrated government and captured the state swiftly to justice.
sot: ke tshepa hore lekala la naha la botjhotjhisi (npa) le tla etsa diphuputso tsa lona ho latela kgothaletso ya komeshene hore ho tle ho tshwarwe baetsi ba bobe bona ka potlako.

eng: the investigating directorate in the npa is now poised to deliver on its crucial mandate, and a dedicated team has been established to pursue these cases.
sot: ho na le moifo o ikgethileng ho npa o tla shebana le dinyewe tsena.

eng: we will be appointing a new head of the investigating directorate following the departure of adv hermione cronje from that position.
sot: re tlameha ho thonya hlooho ya diphuputso ho latela ho itokolla ha moatevoketi hermione cronje mosebetsing ona.

eng: an amendment to the state capture commission regulations in june 2020, empowered the sharing of information between the commission and law enforcement agencies.
sot: diphetoho tse entsweng ka phupjane 2020 melawaneng e laolang komeshene ya dipatlisiso mabapi le kgapo ya puso, di dumella komeshene ho neha makala a qobellang molao dintlha tsa komeshene eo.

eng: this amendment also permitted the employment of the state capture commission personnel by law enforcement agencies.
sot: diphetoho tsena di kenyeletsa ho dumellwa ho hirwa ha mosebeletsi wa komeshene ke lekala le qobellang melao.

eng: these empowering provisions has geared the investigating directorate to more effectively pursue the investigations emanating from the commission.
sot: diphetoho tsena di bebofaletsa lekala la diphuputso mosebetsi wa ho qala diphuputso tsa lona moo komeshene e qetelletseng teng.

eng: we have gratefully acknowledged the offer of support from the private sector to assist in providing those skills which we lack in government to enable investigation and prosecution of crime.
sot: hona jwale re a leboha ka tshehetso eo re e fumanang lekaleng le ikemetseng la ho thusa ka ho fana ka boiphihlelo boo mmuso o se nang bona, hore o kgone ho atleha ho fuputseng le dinyewe tsena.

eng: to ensure that the prosecuting authority remains true to its constitutional obligation and to ensure transparency, we are developing a framework for private sector cooperation that will be managed through national treasury.
sot: ho netefatsa hore lekala la botjhotjhisi le tswela pele le mosebetsi wa lona ho latela molaotheo, le ho netefatsa hore tsohle di etsetswa pepeneneng, re etsa moralo wa ho sebedisana le lekala le ikemetseng, mme ona o tla laolwa ke lefapha la matlotlo.

eng: there are also discussions underway with the judiciary for the creation of special court rolls for state capture and corruption cases.
sot: ho ntse ho na le dipuisano tse tswellang pele le lekala la toka hore ho thehwe makgotla a ikgethang a dinyewe bakeng sa dinyewe tsena tsa kgapo ya puso le bobodu.

eng: while we have taken decisive steps to end the era of state capture, we know that the fight against corruption is far from over.
sot: leha re leka ka hohle hohle ho qeta ketso tsena tsa kgapo ya puso, empa re a tseba hore ha e le ntwa kgahlano le bobodu yona, e sa le hole le ho fela.

eng: even as the country was suffering the devastation of the covid-19 pandemic, companies and individuals were conspiring with public officials to defraud the government of billions of rand in covid-related contracts.
sot: le nakong ena ya koduwa ya covid-19, dikhamphane le batho ba itseng, ba ne ba etsa mmomori le basebeletsi ba mmuso ho leka ho qhekella mmuso tjhelete e ballwang ho dibilione dikonterakeng tse mabapi le covid.

eng: as soon as evidence emerged of this corruption we acted.
sot: hang feela ha bopaki bo hlahella, re tlo nka bohato.

eng: we withdrew certain emergency procurement regulations, set up a fusion centre that brought together various law enforcement agencies, published the details of all covid-related contracts online and instituted the most extensive investigation that the special investigating unit (siu) has undertaken since its formation.
sot: re ile ra tlameha ho emisa dikonteraka tse itseng tsa theko ya ditlhoko mabapi le covid mme ra theha tshebeletso ya kopanelo ya makala a qobellang molao, moo ho neng ho phatlalatswa ka inthanete dintlha tsa dikonteraka tse mabapi le covid mme lekala le ikgethileng la diphuputso (siu) le entse diphuputso tsa lona.

eng: in december, the siu submitted its final report on its investigation into covid-related contracts.
sot: ka tshitwe, siu e nnehile tlaleho ya yona ya diphuputso mabapi le dikonteraka tsa covid.

eng: as a result, 45 matters, with a combined value of r2.1 billion, have been enrolled with the special tribunal.
sot: ka lebaka la sena, ho se ho na le dinyewe tse ka bang 45 tsa tjhelete e bitsang dibilione tse r2.1 tse seng di hlahletswe lekgotlaneng le ikgethang.

eng: the siu has referred 224 government officials for disciplinary action and referred 386 cases for possible prosecution to the npa.
sot: siu e se e kgothaleditse hore basebeletsi ba mmuso ba ka bang 224 ba ye komiting ya kgalemo mme ya romela dinyewe tse 386 ho npa bakeng sa ho tjhotjhiswa.

eng: the presidency has set up mechanisms to monitor implementation of the recommendations of the siu and ensure that government departments and entities act against those who have violated regulations and broken the law.
sot: kantoro ya mopresidente e thehile tsela ya ho beha leihlo hore dikgothaletso tsa siu di a latelwa, mme mmuso le mafapha a ona, a netefatsa hore baetsi ba bobe bona ba fumana kotlo e ba tshwanelang.

eng: the fight against corruption will take on a new intensity thanks to the outcomes of the state capture commission, the strengthening of law enforcement agencies and the implementation of new anti-corruption practices in the public service.
sot: ntwa kgahlano le bobodu e tla tiha jwale, re leboha sephetho sena sa komeshene ya dipatlisiso ka kgapo ya puso, le ho matlafatswa ha makala a qobellang molao le ho kenngwa tshebetsong ha dipehelo tsa setjhaba tsa twantsho ya bobodu.

eng: soes play a vital role in our economy.
sot: dikhamphane tsa mmuso (soe) ke tsa bohlokwa moruong wa naha.

eng: from water and roads, to energy and ports, to defence and aviation, these strategic assets are necessary to keep our country running.
sot: ho tloha ho metsi, ditsela, motlakase le boemakepe, tsa tshireletso le bofofisi, tsena kaofela ke ditshebeletso tsa bohlokwa tsamaisong ya naha.

eng: it is essential that we reverse their decline, and position them to contribute positively.
sot: ho bohlokwa hore re di ahe botjha di tle di tswele naha molemo.

eng: we have therefore embarked on several immediate measures to restore these companies to health, at the same time as we undertake far-reaching reforms that will make our soes more efficient, competitive, accountable and sustainable.
sot: re letsholong la ho tsoseletsa dikhamphane tsena, ka ho le leng re etsa diphetoho tsa hore khamphane tsena di sebetse hantle, di sebetse ka botshepehi le ka tsela ya moshwelella.

eng: the presidential soe council, which i appointed in 2020, has recommended that government adopt a centralised shareholder model for its key commercial state-owned companies.
sot: moifo wa mopresidente o shebaneng le dikhamphane tsa mmuso, o kgethilweng ka 2020, o entse dikgothaletso tsa hore mmuso e be ona o ka sehloohong taolong ya dikhamphane tsena.

eng: this would separate the state’s ownership functions from its policy-making and regulatory functions, minimise the scope for political interference, introduce greater professionalism and manage state assets in a way that protects shareholder value.
sot: sena se tla etsa hore ho bonahale phapang pakeng tsa moo mmusong o sebetsang jwalo ka monga khamphane le moo o behang teng dipehelo tsa tshebetso jwalo ka mmuso.

eng: as part of this, preparatory work has begun for the establishment of a state-owned holding company to house strategic soes and to exercise coordinated shareholder oversight.
sot: sena se tla fokotsa ho kenella ha tsa dipolotiki mme ho etse dikhamphane tsena di tsamaiswe ka tsela ya profeshenale.

eng: to ensure that soes are effectively fulfilling their responsibilities, the presidential soe council is preparing recommendations on soes to be retained, consolidated or disposed of.
sot: ho netefatsa hore dikhamphane tsena tsa mmuso di sebetsa ka nepo, moifo ona wa mopresidente wa dikhamphane tsena, o kgothaletsa hore di nne di tswele pele le ho sebetsa, di kopanywe kapa di fediswe.

eng: any recommendations would be subject to extensive consultation with all stakeholders.
sot: kgothaletso e nngwe le e nngwe re e shebisana le bohle ba amehang.

eng: we are taking steps to safeguard our democracy, protect our economic infrastructure and build safer communities for all.
sot: re nka mehato ya ho sireletsa demokrasi ya rona, meralo ya moruo wa rona le ho aha setjhaba se bolokehileng bakeng sa bohle.

eng: earlier this week, we released the report of the expert panel into the civil unrest in july last year.
sot: botjheng ba beke ena, re phatlaladitse tlaleho ya ditsebi mabapi le merusu ya kgwedi ya phupu ngwahola.

eng: the report paints a deeply disturbing picture of the capabilities of our security services and the structures that exist to coordinate their work.
sot: tlaleho ena, e hlakisa pono e seng ntle ka bokgoni ba makala a rona a tshireletso le a mang a neng a tlameha ho etsa mesebetsi ya ona.

eng: the report concludes that government’s initial handling of the july 2021 events was inept, police operational planning was poor, there was poor coordination between the state security and intelligence services, and police are not always embedded in the communities they serve.
sot: tlaleho ena, e bontsha ha mmuso o bile bohlaswa taolong ya maemo ao a phupu 2021. sepolesa se ne se sa itokisetsa ka nepo, ha ho ka ba ha ba teng tshebedisano mmoho pakeng tsa sona le lekala la mautlwela, mme le sona sepolesa ha se dule se le setjhabeng seo se tlamehang ho se sireletsa.

eng: the expert panel said that if the violence has exposed anything it was the poverty and inequality that is the root cause of the desperation of the people of south africa.
sot: moifo ona wa ditsebi, o bontshitse hore sesosa sa merusu eo e bile bofutsana, le ho se lekalekane ha batho naheng ena.

eng: the expert panel found that cabinet must take overall responsibility for the events of july 2021. this is a responsibility that we acknowledge and accept.
sot: ditsebi tsena di boletse ha kabinete e tlameha ho jara boikarabelo ba merusu eo ya ka kgwedi ya phupu 2021. bona ke boikarabelo boo re bo dumelang re bileng re bo amohelang.

eng: we will, as recommended by the panel, develop and drive a national response plan to address the weaknesses that the panel has identified.
sot: ho ya ka kgothaletso ya ditsebi, re tla rala leano la ho shebana le bofokodi bona boo ditsebi di llileng ka bona.

eng: we will begin immediately by filling critical vacancies and addressing positions affected by suspensions in the state security agency and crime intelligence.
sot: re tlo phakisa ho tlatsa dikgeo tsa bohlokwa, le ho lekola kgahlamelo ya ho emiswa mosebetsing ha basebeletsi ba lefapheng la tshireletso le la mautlwela.

eng: we will soon be announcing leadership changes in a number of security agencies to strengthen our security structures.
sot: haufinyane re tla phatlalatsa diphetoho bookameding ba makala a tshireletso, e le ho matlafatsa lekala lena.

eng: the staffing of the public order policing unit of the south african police service will be brought to an appropriate level, with appropriate training courses in place.
sot: basebeletsi ba sepolesa sa setjhaba lekaleng la sepolesa sa naha, ba tla tlameha ho fumana thupelo e nepahetseng e tla dumella hore ba be maemong a lokelang.

eng: the ongoing damage to and theft of economic infrastructure has damaged confidence and severely constrained economic growth, investment and job creation.
sot: tshenyo le boshodu bo tswellang pele meralong ya moruo, bo na le kgahlamelo e mpe ntlafatsong ya moruo, ya matsete le thehong ya menyetla ya mesebetsi.

eng: at the same time, we need to confront the criminal gangs that invade construction sites and other business places to extort money from companies.
sot: re boetse hape re tlameha ho lwantsha ditlokotsebe tsena tse lwantshang basebeletsi ba tsa kaho ka maikemisetso a ho ba qhekella tjhelete.

eng: this requires a focused and coordinated response.
sot: ena ke pharela e hlokang tharollo e hlophisitsweng hantle.

eng: government has therefore established specialise multi-disciplinary units to address economic sabotage, extortion at construction sites and vandalism of infrastructure.
sot: mmuso o thehile lekala la kopanelo le tlo lwantsha bothata ba tshenyo ya ka boomo moruong, tlhaselo ya basebeletsi ba tsa kaho le tshenyo ya meralo ya motheo.

eng: we will make resources available to recruit and train an additional 12 000 new police personnel to ensure that the south african police service urgently gets the capacity it needs.
sot: re tla matlafatsa sepolesa sa rona ka ho hira mapolesa a matjha a 12 000. e nngwe karolo e hlokang ho tsoseletswa ka potlako, ke ya sepolesa sa setjhaba ka maikemisetso a ho matlafatsa tshebedisano e ntle pakeng tsa mapolesa le setjhaba seo a sebetsang ho sona.

eng: another area of immediate attention will be the re-establishment of community policing forums to improve relations and coordination between local police and residents of the areas they serve.
sot: ho a hlaka tlalehong ya ditsebi hore re tlameha ho nka bohato bo matla ntlafatsong ya tshireletso ya naha ya rona.

eng: i am calling on all south africans through their various formations to participate in developing our national security strategy.
sot: ke ipiletsa ho maafrika borwa ohle ho nka karolo ho thehweng ha leano la naha la tshireletso.

eng: i will be approaching parliament’s presiding officers to request that parliament plays a key role in facilitating inclusive processes of consultation.
sot: ke tla kopa batsamaisi ba palamene hore ba kope palamente hore e nke karolo tabeng ena, esitana le ho buisana le bohle ba amehang.

eng: the security services have been tasked by the national security council to urgently develop implementation plans that address the range of recommendations made by the expert panel.
sot: moifo wa naha wa tshireletso, o laetse lekala la tshireletso ho potlakisa ho kenya tshebetsong dikgothaletso tsa moifo wa ditsebi.

eng: these measures will go a long way to address the serious concerns about the breakdown of law and order in society.
sot: mehato ya teng, e tla shebana le mathata a hore setjhaba ha se ikobele molao.

eng: this year, we are intensifying the fight against gender-based violence and femicide through implementation of the national strategic plan on gender-based violence and femicide, and other measures to promote the empowerment of women.
sot: selemong sena, re tlo tiisa ntwa kgahlano le tlhekefetso ya bonng le dipolao tsa basadi ka ho kenya tshebetsong leano la naha la twantsho ya tlhekefetso ya bonng le dipolao tsa basadi, mmoho le maano a mang a ho matlafatsa basadi.

eng: earlier this month, i signed into law three new pieces of legislation, which has strengthened the criminal justice system, promoting accountability across the state and supporting survivors.
sot: mathwasong a kgwedi ena, ke saenne melao e meraro e metjha e tlo matlafatsa lekala la rona le lwantshang botlokotsebe.

eng: the implementation of this legislation will go a long way to ensuring that cases are successfully prosecuted, that survivors are protected and that there are more effective deterrents in place.
sot: melao ena e bile e netefatsa hore mmuso o tshehetsa mahlatsipa a diketsahalo tsena.

eng: we have made significant progress in reducing the backlog in dna processing, reducing it from 210 000 exhibits in april 2021 to around 58 000 at present.
sot: re se re hatetse pele ho leka ho fokotsa ho pakellana ha mosebetsi wa ditshebeletso tsa lefutso, ka ho o fokotsa ho tloha ho 210 000 ka mmesa 2021 mme ha jwale ho setse fela e 58 000. tlhekefetso ya bonng e ke ke ya fela ha feela makala ohle a setjhaba a sa kopane mmoho ho tla le mekgwa ya ho hlola mokgwa ona o mobe.

eng: however, the fight against gender-based violence will never be won unless, as society, we mobilise all formations and all citizens behind a sustained programme of social action.
sot: jwalo ka ha covid-19 e sentse hakana, re tlameha ho hopola hore le bophelo ba setjhaba bo itshetlehileng ntlafatsong ya moruo le ya bodulo.

eng: as the covid-19 pandemic has starkly demonstrated, a nation’s health is inextricably linked with its economic progress and social development.
sot: re tla tswela pele le ho netefatsa hore motho ohle ho sa natsehe hore o kgona ho lefa kapa tjhe, o fumana tshebeletso e nepahetseng ya tsa bophelo bo botle.

eng: we will therefore continue with the work underway to ensure universal health coverage for everyone in south africa, regardless of their ability to pay.
sot: jwalo ka ha setjhaba se sa ntsane se ntsha maikutlo a sona ka molao ona wa leano la ditjhelete ho tsa bophelo bo botle, ho se ho na le kgatelo pele ho kengweng ha lona tshebetsong.

eng: more than 59 million people are registered in the health patient registration system.
sot: ke batho ba fetang dimilione tse 59 ba ngodisitsweng dintlheng tsa polokelo ya dintlha tsa bakudi.

eng: by september 2021, more than 56 000 additional health workers had been recruited and more than 46 000 community health workers integrated into the public health system.
sot: ka loetse 2021, ho ile ha hirwa basebeletsi ba bang ba fetang 56 000 ba tsa bophelo bo botle, mme ha boela hape ha nkuwa basebeletsi ba setjhaba ba 46 000 ba kengwa ho tsa bophelo bo botle.

eng: for the last two years, the education of our children and young people has been severely disrupted.
sot: dilemong tse pedi tse fetileng, thuto ya bana ba rona e phatsamisehile haholo.

eng: as we return to normal educational activity, we will work harder to ensure that all learners and students get the quality education they need and deserve.
sot: jwalo ka ha bana ba se ba tla ya sekolong kamehla, re tla sebetsa ka thata ho netefatsa hore bana ba rona ba fumana thuto ya boleng, e ba tshwanelang.

eng: fellow south africans,government must work for the people.
sot: maafrika borwa a heso,mmuso o tlameha ho sebeletsa setjhaba.

eng: that is why our foremost priority is to build a capable, ethical and developmental state.
sot: ke ka hona re ikemiseditseng ho ba mmuso o nang le bokgoni le ntshetso pele.

eng: we will soon be finalising a framework for the professionalisation of the public service.
sot: haufinyane, re tla phethela moralo wa hore mmuso o sebetse ka tsela ya profeshenale.

eng: this will include tighter measures for recruitment of public servants, continuous professional development through the national school of government and partnerships between state bodies, professional associations and universities.
sot: sena se tla kenyeletsa dipehelo tse matla ho hirweng ha basebeletsi ba mmuso, ntshetsopeleng ya thupello ka mokgwa wa thupello ya botsamisi ba mmuso, mmoho le tshebedisano mmoho le mekgatlo e laolang mangolo a profeshenale mmoho le diyunivesithi.

eng: lifestyle audits are already being implemented across the public service.
sot: ho hlahlojwa ha tsela eo basebeletsi ba mmuso ba phelang ka yona, ho se ho qadile mafapheng ohle.

eng: this year, we will continue with the implementation of the ddm.
sot: le selemong sena, re tlo tswela pele le ho kenya ddm tshebetsong.

eng: this model brings all three spheres of government together with other social partners in every district to grow inclusive local economies and improve the lives of citizens.
sot: leano lena, le kopanya maemo ohle a puso mmoho le mahlahana a ona diterekeng tsohle bakeng sa ho hodisa moruo le ntlafatso ya maphelo a batho.

eng: in particular, the ddm facilitates integrated planning and budgeting across spheres of government and improves integration of national projects at a district level.
sot: leano lena la ddm, le thusa ho potlakisa ho etsa meralo ho kenyeletsa le ya ditjhelete maemong ohle a mmuso, mme le thusa le ho kgona ho fihlisa diprojeke tsa boemo ba naha boemong ba ditereke.

eng: while there are many parts of the state that require much work, there are institutions that continue to serve the people of this country effectively and efficiently.
sot: leha ho na le dikarolo tsa ditshebeletso tsa mmuso tse hlokang ho lokiswa, empa ka ho le leng, ho ntse ho na le tse kgonang ho thusa setjhaba ka nepo le ka tshwanelo.

eng: one such institution is the sars, which will be 25 years old this year.
sot: e nngwe ya ditshebeletso tseo, ke ya sars, e tla beng e qeta dilemo tse 25 selemong sena.

eng: while sars was badly damaged by state capture, it has made remarkable progress in restoring its integrity, credibility and performance.
sot: leha sars e thefutswe ke diketso tsa kgapo ya puso, empa e kgonne ho atleha ho sebetsa ka nepo, le botshepehi.

eng: since its formation, sars has collected some r16 trillion for the country’s social and economic development.
sot: haesale e ne e thehwe, sars e se e bokeleditse tjhelete e ballwang ho ditrilione tse r16 bakeng sa ntlafatso ya moruo le naha.

eng: this revenue has enabled government to improve the lives of millions through the provision of healthcare, education, social grants and other basic services.
sot: lekala lena, le entse hore mmuso o kgone ho ntlafatsa maphelo a dimilione tsa batho ka ditshebeletso tsa bophelo bo botle, tsa thuso ya ditjhelete le ditshebeletso tsa sethatho.

eng: a capable state is not only about the quality of public servants and the efficiency of institutions.
sot: puso e nepahetseng ha e bonwe ka basebeletsi ba sebetsang hantle le makala a teng a sebetsang hantle feela.

eng: it is also, fundamentally, about how citizens are empowered to participate.
sot: puso e nepahetse e boetse e bonahala le ka moo setjhaba se fuwang monyetla wa ho nka karolo le sona.

eng: we must work together to ensure that platforms like schools governing bodies and community policing forums are more active and inclusive.
sot: re tlameha ho netefatsa hore mekgatlo e kang ya taolo ya dikolo, le ya sepolesa sa setjhaba e fumana tlhokomelo e e hlokang.

eng: a vibrant civil society is crucial for a capable state and for development.
sot: setjhaba se mafolofolo se bohlokwa bakeng sa ntlafatso le puso e nepahetseng.

eng: we will therefore be working with social partners to convene the long-awaited social sector summit.
sot: re tlo sebetsa le mahlahana a rona ho lokisetsa ho bitsa kopano ya mekgatlo ya setjhaba eo e leng kgale e emetswe ka mahlo a mafubedu.

eng: this summit will seek to improve the interface between the state and civil society and address the challenges that non-governmental organisations and community-based organisations face.
sot: kopano ena, e tla rarolla mathata pakeng tsa mmuso le setjhaba, le pakeng tsa mmuso le mekgatlo ena e seng tlasa mmuso mathateng ao e kopanang le ona.

eng: our country has suffered several damaging blows in recent times.
sot: naha ya rona e bile le mathata nakong e sa tswa feta.

eng: a confluence of forces, many of them outside of our control, has brought us to where we are now.
sot: ho na le maqulwana a karohano ao e leng ona a re behileng maemong ao re leng ho ona kajeno.

eng: indeed, we are engaged in a battle for the soul of this country.
sot: ke nnete, re ntweng ya ho pholosa naha ya rona.

eng: but there can be no doubt that we will win.
sot: jwang kapa jwang, teng re tla hlola.

eng: i ask every south african to rally together in our fight against corruption, in our fight to create jobs, in our fight to achieve a more just and equal society.
sot: ha re kopaneng re le maafrika borwa re lwantsheng bobodu, re theheng mesebetsi, re lwaneleng toka le tekatekano setjhabeng sa habo rona.

eng: we have faced many crises in our past, and we have overcome them.
sot: re kopane le mathata nakong e fetileng, ra a hlola.

eng: we have been confronted with difficult choices, and we have made them.
sot: re ile ra tlameha ho nka qeto tse thata, mme ra kgona.

eng: in trying times, we have shown courage and resiliencetime and time again, we have pulled ourselves back from the brink of despair and inspired hope, renewal and progress.
sot: re se re bontshitse sebete le matla dinakong tsa mathata,ka nako e nngwe, ke bona re lahla tshepo, re nyahama, mme re kgutlela morao.

eng: now, we must do so again.
sot: jwale ha re a tlameha ho etsa jwalo hape.

eng: let us forge a new consensus to confront a new reality, a consensus that unites us behind our shared determination to reform our economy and rebuild our institutions.
sot: ha re tshwaraneng mme re tobaneng le maemo a re tobileng, re kopaneng re tsoseletseng moruo le ditshebeletso tsa rona tsa setjhaba.

eng: let us get to work.
sot: ha re sebetseng mmoho hle.

eng: let us rebuild our country.
sot: ha re aheng naha ya habo rona botjha.

eng: speaker of the national assembly, ms nosiviwe mapisa-nqakula, chairperson of the national council of provinces, mr amos masondo, deputy president david mabuza, the executive mayor of the city of cape town, mr geordin hill-lewis, former president thabo mbeki, former deputy president baleka mbete, president of the pan african parliament, the right honourable chief fortune charumbira, chief justice raymond zondo and members of the judiciary, heads of institutions supporting democracy, deputy president of the governing party, mr paul mashatile and leaders of all parties, members of parliament, fellow south africans, it is a great honour to stand before you this evening to present the state of the nation.
sot: motsamaisi wa dipuisano lekgotleng la naha la ketsamelao, mme nosiviwe mapisa-nqakula,modulasetulo wa lekgotla la naha la diprovinse, ntate amos masondo, motlatsi wa mopresidente david mabuza,majoro wa phethahatso wa motse wa kapa, ntate geordin hill-lewis,mopresidente wa mehleng thabo mbeki, motlatsi wa mopresidente wa mehleng baleka mbete,mopresidente wa palamente ya dinaha tsa afrika, morena e moholo morena fortune charumbira,moahlodi e moholo raymond zondo le ditho tsa makgotla a boahlodi,dihlooho tsa mekgatlo e tshehetsang demokrasi,motlatsi wa mopresidente wa mokga o busang, ntate paul mashatile le baetapele ba mekga yohle,ditho tsa palamente,maafrika borwa a heso ke tlotla e kgolo ho nna ha ke eme ka pele ho lona phirimaneng ena, mme ke fana ka puo ya boemo ba naha.

eng: for we are a nation defined not by the oceans and rivers that form the boundaries of our land.
sot: hobane re setjhaba se sa hlalosweng ke mawatle le dinoka tseo e leng meedi ya naha ya rona.

eng: we are not defined by the minerals under our earth or the spectacular landscape above it.
sot: ha re hlaloswe ke dirashwa tse ka mpeng ya lefatshe la rona kapa ke naha e kgahlang mahlo e ka hodima lefatshe la rona.

eng: we are not even defined by the languages we speak or the songs we sing or the work we do.
sot: ha re hlaloswe le ke dipuo tseo re di buang kapa dipina tseo re di binang kapa mosebetsi oo re o etsang.

eng: we are, at our most essential, a nation defined by hope and resilience.
sot: sebopehong sa rona sa bohlokwa ka ho fetisisa, re setjhaba se hlaloswang ke tshepo le ho tiisetsa.

eng: it was hope that sustained our struggle for freedom, and it is hope that swells our sails as we steer our country out of turbulent waters to calmer seas.
sot: ke tshepo e ile ya fa boitseko ba rona ba tokoloho mokoka, hape ke tshepo e re fang matla ha re ntsha naha ya rona merusung re e isa kgutsong.

eng: even in these trying times, it is hope that sustains us and fuels our determination to overcome even the greatest of difficulties.
sot: le dinakong tsena tsa diteko, ke tshepo e re fang mokoka hape e phedisang boikemisetso ba rona ba ho hola, leho hlola mathata a maholo ka ho fetisisa.

eng: just three years ago, our country was devastated by the worst global pandemic in living memory.
sot: dilemong tse tharo feela tse fetileng, naha ya rona e ne e hateletswe ke sewa se sebe ka ho fetisisa sa lefatshe nakong ya dilemo tse ka hopolehang.

eng: thousands of lives were lost, companies closed, jobs were lost.
sot: diketekete tsa maphelo di ile tsa lahleha, dikhampani tsa kwalwa le mesebetsi ya lahleha.

eng: covid-19 did not browbeat us into submission or disillusionment.
sot: covid-19 ha e ka ya atleha ho re susumeletsa ho ineheleng le ho fellweng ke tshepo.

eng: working together, we overcame that crisis, and we have started to recover.
sot: re sebetsa mmoho, re ile ra hlola mathata ao, mme re se re qadile ho boela re kgutlela boemong ba rona ba pele.

eng: today our economy is larger than it was before the pandemic.
sot: kajeno moruo wa rona o moholo ho feta kamoo o neng o le kateng pele ho sewa.

eng: between the third quarters of 2021 and 2022, around one and a half million new jobs were created in our economy.
sot: pakeng tsa dikotare tsa boraro tsa selemo sa 2021 le sa 2022, mesebetsi e metjha e ka bang milione le halofo e ile ya thewa morung wa rona.

eng: the presidential employment stimulus has provided work and livelihood opportunities to more than one million people.
sot: morero wa mopresidente wa tlhasimollo ya mesebetsi o hlahisitse menyetla ya ho sebetsa le ya boiphediso ho batho ba fetang milione.

eng: last year, our matriculants defied the effects of the pandemic to achieve a pass rate of 80% and we congratulate them for that great achievement.
sot: selemong se fetileng, baithuti ba rona ba materiki ba ile ba hanyetsana le ditlamorao tsa sewa sena ka ho atleha ho fumana 80% ya sekgahla sa ho pasa.

eng: we see this spirit of determination in our artists, musicians, actors, authors and sportsmen and women, who are making waves at home, on the continent and beyond our shores.
sot: re bona moya wa boikemisetso ho banono ba rona, dibini tsa rona, bangodi ba rona le boradipapadi ba rona ba batona le ba batshehadi, ba ipabolang ka hare ho naha, kontinenteng, esita le ka mose ho mawatle a rona.

eng: banyana banyana made us proud when they won the women’s africa cup of nations to become the champions of africa.
sot: banyana banyana ba re entse motlotlo ha ba hapa mohope wa basadi wa dinaha tsa afrika, mme e ba bommampodi ba afrika.

eng: zakes bantwini, nomcebo zikode and wouter kellerman have made us proud at the grammy awards for their collaboration, bayethe.
sot: zakes bantwini, nomcebo zikode le wouter kellerman ba re entse motlotlo dikgaung tsa grammy ka tshebetsommoho ya bona, bayethe.

eng: what we have achieved as a nation over the past year, despite our challenges, remind us that the promise of south africa is alive.
sot: tseo re atlehileng ho tsona re le setjhaba nakong ya selemo se fetileng, ho sa natsehe diphephetso tsa rona, di re hopotsa hore tshepiso ya afrika borwa e a phela.

eng: the progress we have seen should give us courage as we look to a better future.
sot: tswelopele eo re e boneng e tshwanela ho re neha sebete nakong ena eo re tshepang hore re tla ba le bokamoso bo tjhatsi.

eng: and yet, i address you this evening, in homes across the country, many people are suffering, many are worried, many are uncertain and many are without hope.
sot: empa, hape, nakong eo ke buang le lona phirimaneng ena ka yona, malapeng a naheng ya rona ka bophara, batho ba bangata ba hatellehile, ba bangata ba tshwenyehile maikutlo, ba bangata ba a qeaqea, mme ba bangata ha ba na tshepo.

eng: but of this i am certain.
sot: empa ha ke qeaqeye.

eng: whatever the difficulties of the moment, whatever crises we face, we will rise to meet them together and, together, we will overcome them.
sot: le ha e ka ba mathata afe a nako ena, le ha e le dife ditsietsi tseo re shebaneng le tsona, re tla phahama, mme re shebane le tsona re le mmoho, hape, mmoho re tla di hlola.

eng: this, we will be able to do if we work together and leave no one behind.
sot: sena, re tla kgona ho se etsa haeba re sebetsa mmoho, mme ho se eo re mo siyang morao.

eng: we gather here at a time of crisis.
sot: re phuthehela mona ka nako ya tsietsi.

eng: our country has, for many months, endured a debilitating electricity shortage that has caused immense damage to our economy.
sot: nakong ya dikgwedi tse ngata jwale, naha ya rona e emelane re kgaello ya motlakase e tetebetsang pelo e bakileng tshenyo e kgolo moruong wa rona.

eng: and for two years before that, our society was devastated by the covid-19 pandemic that caused great loss of life and much hardship.
sot: hape, ka dilemo tse pedi pele ho moo, setjhaba sa rona se ile sa thefulwa ke sewa sa covid-19 se ileng sa baka tahlehelo e kgolo ya maphelo le tshotleho e kgolo.

eng: the pandemic worsened a situation of deep unemployment, as the country lost two million jobs.
sot: sewa sena se ile sa mpefatsa boemo ba leqeme le leholo la mesebetsi, jwalo ka ha naha e ile ya lahlehelwa ke dimilione tse pedi tsa mesebetsi.

eng: the pandemic negatively affected livelihoods and increased poverty.
sot: sewa sena se ile sa ama hampe mekgwa ya boiphediso, mme sa eketsa bofuma.

eng: in july 2021, we experienced the worst public violence and destruction in the history of our democracy, causing over 300 deaths.
sot: ka kgwedi ya phupu selemong sa 2021, re ile ra ba le merusu ya setjhaba e mebe ka ho fetisisa le tshenyo e so ka e eba teng nalaneng ya demokrasi ya rona, e ileng ya baka mafu a fetang 300. ngwahola, dikarolo tsa kapa botjhabela, kwazulu-natal le leboya bophirima di ile tsa hlaselwa ke dikgohola tse tshabehang tse ileng tsa baka tahlehelo e kgolo ya maphelo, tshenyo ya metse ya bodulo le tshenyo ya metheo ya tshebetso ya moruo.

eng: and now, persistent load-shedding is impeding our recovery from the effects of these events.
sot: hape hona jwale, ho qonolwa ho sa kgaotseng ha phepelo ya motlakase ho thibela ho hlaphohelwa ha rona ditlamoraong tsa diketsahalo tsena.

eng: we know that without a reliable supply of electricity, businesses cannot grow, assembly lines cannot run, crops cannot be irrigated and basic services are interrupted.
sot: re a tseba hore kantle ho phepelo e tshepahalang ya motlakase, dikgwebo di ke ke tsa hola, difeme tse ahang dikoloi di ke ke tsa sebetsa, dijalo di ke ke tsa nosetswa, le ditshebeletso tsa mantlha di a sitiseha.

eng: load-shedding means that households and supermarkets are unable to keep food fresh, water supply is often disrupted, traffic lights do not work and streets are not lit at night.
sot: ho qonolwa ha phepelo ya motlakase ho bolela hore malapa le disupamakete ha di kgone ho boloka dijo di le foreshe, phepelo ya metsi e a kgaoha ka dinako tse ding, mabone a sephethephethe ha a sebetse le diterata ha di kganye bosiu.

eng: without a reliable supply of electricity, our efforts to grow an inclusive economy that creates jobs and reduces poverty will not succeed.
sot: kantle ho phepelo e tshepahalang ya motlakase, matsapa a rona a ho hodisa moruo o kenyeletsang bohle, hape o thehang mesebetsi, le o fokotsang bofuma, a ke ke a atleha.

eng: therefore, as we outline our agenda for the year ahead, our most immediate task is to dramatically reduce the severity of load-shedding in the coming months and ultimately end load-shedding altogether.
sot: ka hona, ha re rala lenaneo la rona bakeng sa selemo seo re keneng ho sona, mosebetsi wa rona wa kapelepele ke ho fokotsa ka matla sekgahla sena se seholo sa ho qonolwa ha phepelo ya motlakase dikgweding tse tlang, mme re qetelle re fedisitse ho qonolwa ha phepelo ya motlakase ka botlalo.

eng: under these conditions, we cannot proceed as we usually would.
sot: tlasa maemo ana, re ke ke ra tswela pele jwalo ka tlwaelo.

eng: the people of south africa want action, they want solutions and they want government to work for them.
sot: batho ba afrika borwa ba batla hore ho nkuwe mehato, ba batla ditharollo, hape ba batla hore mmuso o ba sebeletse.

eng: they simply want to know when a problem like load-shedding will be brought to an end.
sot: ba batla feela ho tseba hore na bothata bo tshwanang le ba ho qonolwa ha phepelo ya motlakase bo tla fediswa neng.

eng: we are, therefore, focused on those actions that will make a meaningful difference now, that will enable real progress within the next year and that will lay a foundation for a sustained recovery into the future.
sot: ke ka hona re tsepamisitseng maikutlo hodima mehato e tla tlisa phapang e bonahalang hona jwale, e tla dumella hore ho be teng tswelopele ya nnete nakong ya selemo se tlang, le e tla theha moralo o tsitsitseng bakeng la tlhaphohelo e nang le mokoka bakeng sa ho ya pele.

eng: we are not presenting new plans, nor are we outlining here the full programme of government.
sot: puong ena ha re hlahise meralo e metjha, kapa hona ho lokodisa mona lenaneo le feletseng la mmuso.

eng: rather we are concentrating on those issues that concern south africans the most: load-shedding.
sot: empa re tsepamisa maikutlo hodima dintlha tseno tse ngogorehisang maafrika borwa ka ho fetisisa: ho qonolwa ha phepelo ya motlakase.

eng: unemployment.
sot: leqeme la mesebetsi.

eng: poverty and the rising cost of living.
sot: bofuma le ditjeo tse nyolohang tsa ditlhoko tsa boiphediso.

eng: crime and corruption.
sot: ditlolo tsa molao le bobodu.

eng: there are no easy solutions to any of these challenges.
sot: diphephetsong tsena kaofela ha ho le ha e le efe e hlokang tharollo e bobebe.

eng: yet we have the strength, the means and the wherewithal to overcome them.
sot: empa re na le matla, bokgoni le tsohle tse hlokehang bakeng la ho hlola tsena.

eng: if we work together and act boldly and decisively, leaving no one behind, we will be able to resolve our challenges.
sot: haeba re sebetsa mmoho, mme re nka bohato ka sebete le ka tiyo, ho se eo re mo siyang morao, re tla ba le hona ho rarolla diphephetso tsa rona.

eng: this state of the nation address (sona) is about seeing hope where there is despair.
sot: puo ena ya boemo ba naha (sona) ke ya ho hlahisa tshepo moo ho nang le ho tsieleha.

eng: it is about showing a way out of these crises.
sot: ke ya ho supa lekgalo la ho tswa ditsietsing tsena.

eng: this evening, we will give an account of our progress in implementing the commitments we made in last year’s sona.
sot: phirimaneng ena, re tla fana ka tlaleho ya tswelopele ya rona ho phethahatseng boitlamo boo re bo entseng ho sona ya selemo se fetileng.

eng: over the course of the last year, we have laid a firm foundation based on the commitments we made for faster growth through our investment drive, economic reforms, public employment programmes and an expanding infrastructure programme.
sot: boleleleng ba selemo se fetileng, re ile ra etsa motheo o matla bakeng la boitlamo boo re bo entseng malebana le kgolo e potlakileng ka morero wa rona wa matsete, diphetoho tsa moruo, mananeo a mesebetsi ya setjhaba le lenaneo la katoloso ya metheo ya tshebetso ya moruo.

eng: what is clear from our experience of the last few years – indeed from our history as a democracy – is that we are not a people easily resigned to our fate.
